description: This course covers the exam objectives of EC-Council's Certified Incident Handler (ECIH) program.  It discusses the basic skills to handle and respond to security events and addresses various underlying principles and techniques for detecting and responding to current and emerging computer security threats.

Adam Gordon is going to go ahead and

what to expect within this show series.

00:00:13.510 --> 00:00:15.140
Thank you for joining us today, Adam.

6
00:00:15.140 --> 00:00:16.190
>> Thank you.

7
00:00:16.190 --> 00:00:16.810
Hello, everybody.

8
00:00:16.810 --> 00:00:17.790
Hopefully everyone's doing well.

9
00:00:17.790 --> 00:00:19.690
Looking forward to spending time with you.

10
00:00:19.690 --> 00:00:23.660
When we talk about the EC Council
Certified Incident Handler material,

11
00:00:23.660 --> 00:00:26.810
what we're really focusing on is
the understanding of what it means to

12
00:00:26.810 --> 00:00:30.520
be an incident responder,
an incident handler, an incident manager.

13
00:00:30.520 --> 00:00:34.470
As an IT security professional, we're
gonna be talking about the methodology,

14
00:00:34.470 --> 00:00:37.370
the techniques,
the thought process, the tools and

15

the strategies associated
with incident handling and

16
00:00:40.260 --> 00:00:45.020
incident response in the enterprise or in

17

We'll be talking about
things like risk assessment.

18
00:00:46.750 --> 00:00:48.420
Why is risk so important?

19

What does risk have to do

20
00:00:50.480 --> 00:00:52.330
Well, come on back and talk to us and

00:00:52.330 --> 00:00:54.210
we'll be happy to talk
about that with you.

22
00:00:54.210 --> 00:00:56.590
What about instant response and
handling steps?

23
00:00:56.590 --> 00:01:01.310
What about the concept of the CERT,
the C, E, R, T, the CSIRT, C, S, I, R,

24
00:01:01.310 --> 00:01:05.270
T, computer security instant response,
computer emergency response.

25
00:01:05.270 --> 00:01:07.180
We'll define and talk about these terms.

26
00:01:07.180 --> 00:01:10.840
We're gonna talk about how to handle
network and security related incidents.

27
00:01:10.840 --> 00:01:13.380
How to handle malicious code incidents.

28
00:01:13.380 --> 00:01:15.610
What happens when somebody
infects us with malware?

29
00:01:15.610 --> 00:01:17.290
How do we address those concerns?

30
00:01:17.290 --> 00:01:21.220
How do we handle insider threats when
somebody that we work with perhaps is

31
00:01:21.220 --> 00:01:25.650
the threat source, the bad actor, that is
engaging in activity that leads to risk?

32
00:01:25.650 --> 00:01:26.510
How do we address that?

33
00:01:26.510 --> 00:01:27.690
How do we find that out?

34
00:01:27.690 --> 00:01:30.320
Come back and join us, and
we'll be talking more about that.

35
00:01:30.320 --> 00:01:32.490
Forensic analysis and incident response.

36
00:01:32.490 --> 00:01:36.500
How do we know, once we find out
that there's been an incident and

37
00:01:36.500 --> 00:01:40.270
we have evidence that points us in that
direction, how do we deal with that?

38
00:01:40.270 --> 00:01:43.750
And how do we capture that evidence
in a way that allows us to establish

39
00:01:43.750 --> 00:01:46.870
beyond reasonable doubt a chain
of custody of evidence?

40
00:01:46.870 --> 00:01:49.550
And the ability to handle that evidence so
that if and

41
00:01:49.550 --> 00:01:55.050
when it is necessary to show up in a court
of law and to describe what we found,

42
00:01:55.050 --> 00:01:58.710
and to testify as to the events
that occurred, we could do so

43
00:01:58.710 --> 00:02:02.170
authoritatively and we can stand on
the evidence that we have captured and

44
00:02:02.170 --> 00:02:05.180
we have cataloged,
we have reported on, we have analyzed.

45
00:02:05.180 --> 00:02:07.370
Because we've done so
in a forensically sound way.

46
00:02:07.370 --> 00:02:09.130
We'll talk about incident reporting,
incident recovery.

47
00:02:09.130 --> 00:02:10.460
And of course, topic near and

48
00:02:10.460 --> 00:02:13.780
dear to my heart and Cherokee's,
we'll be talking about security policy and

49
00:02:13.780 --> 00:02:17.800
law and the impact of policy and
law on the incident handling profession.

50
00:02:17.800 --> 00:02:20.460
Encourage you to all come on back,
take a look at all that with us.

51
00:02:20.460 --> 00:02:21.500
Spend some time with us.

52
00:02:21.500 --> 00:02:24.270
And as always,
make sure that you are selective and

53
00:02:24.270 --> 00:02:27.910
watch what you want to understand and
find out about in this series of episodes.

54
00:02:27.910 --> 00:02:30.660
But keep in mind, there may be a part one,
part two, part three.

55
00:02:30.660 --> 00:02:34.350
We often encourage you to watch
those episodes in sequential order.

56
00:02:34.350 --> 00:02:36.600
If you missed something,
go back and watch them again.

57
00:02:36.600 --> 00:02:37.520
That's why we're record them and

58

why you can play them back
whenever you wanna look at them.

59
00:02:39.860 --> 00:02:41.200
Looking forward to spending time with you.

60
00:02:41.200 --> 00:02:43.400
As always, please come on back and see us.

61
00:02:43.400 --> 00:02:46.340
And when you do,
make sure you bring comfy clothes.

62
00:02:46.340 --> 00:02:47.542
What did you say, popcorn?

63
00:02:47.542 --> 00:02:50.430
>> Popcorn. [LAUGH] >> Bring popcorn and
bring a notepad and make some notes and

64
00:02:50.430 --> 00:02:52.050
write down all those
things that are important.

65
00:02:52.050 --> 00:02:53.694
And make sure that as you're doing so

66
00:02:53.694 --> 00:02:56.559
you thinking about how you're
gonna prepare for this exam and or

67
00:02:56.559 --> 00:03:00.061
the information necessary to relay this
to your professional field, and to do

68
00:03:00.061 --> 00:03:03.669
this in the real world as you look to
become more educated, more knowledgeable,

69
00:03:03.669 --> 00:03:07.097
and of course, more valuable to your

70

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam begin their foray into another great EC-Council certification, the Certified Incident Handler(E|CIH). They kick things off by discussing the foundational knowledge inherent to any CIH. This includes defining a security incident, classifying assets and data, and explaining some of the not-so-glamorous aspects of the job.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.003 --> 00:00:04.997
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're

2
00:00:04.997 --> 00:00:11.726
watching ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:11.726 --> 00:00:13.815
>> All right, greetings, everyone and

4
00:00:13.815 --> 00:00:16.720
welcome to another exciting
episode of ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:16.720 --> 00:00:19.270
I'm your host, Daniel Lowry and
in today's episode,

6
00:00:19.270 --> 00:00:24.580
we are kicking off our new series on
the certified incident handler series.

7
00:00:24.580 --> 00:00:27.720
And of course joining me in the studio,
the man who handles all sorts of

8
00:00:27.720 --> 00:00:30.690
incidents, you know him, you love him,
he's our good friend, Mr Adam Gordon.

9
00:00:30.690 --> 00:00:32.760
Adam, welcome back, so
glad to have you, how's it going?

10
00:00:32.760 --> 00:00:35.294
>> [LAUGH] Thank you very much.
It's going well, good to be back, and

11
00:00:35.294 --> 00:00:39.780
always nice to be able to spend sometime
here with the lovely people at ITPro TV.

12
00:00:39.780 --> 00:00:43.110
Daniel is not included in that but
everybody else is included in that.

13
00:00:43.110 --> 00:00:44.260
You are lovely, I'm only kidding.

14
00:00:44.260 --> 00:00:45.111
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so

15
00:00:45.111 --> 00:00:47.867
we're gonna talk a little bit
about incident handling, and

16
00:00:47.867 --> 00:00:51.488
specifically I thought we would start
out if that's okay with you, really that

17
00:00:51.488 --> 00:00:55.217
kind of chanting, for just a few minutes
at a high level About what incidents are,

18
00:00:55.217 --> 00:00:58.550
what the concept of a security
incident is, where it comes from.

19
00:00:58.550 --> 00:01:02.170
We have lots of different definitions,
right, in theory, for what an incident is.

20
00:01:02.170 --> 00:01:05.030
An incident could be something
that has an unknown or

21
00:01:05.030 --> 00:01:06.990
unintended consequence, for instance.

22
00:01:06.990 --> 00:01:09.170
So if we just think about
that as a starting point,

23
00:01:09.170 --> 00:01:12.570
we can begin to think about
what our definition may be.

24
00:01:12.570 --> 00:01:14.200
So let me ask you a question Dan.

25
00:01:14.200 --> 00:01:17.440
I know you're always want to help me
out when we have these conversations.

26
00:01:17.440 --> 00:01:20.520
So from your experience, and
you had a lot of experience in

27
00:01:20.520 --> 00:01:23.300
these kind of variance given all
the work you've done over the years and

28
00:01:23.300 --> 00:01:25.890
you're like shutting about
the various things you've done.

29
00:01:25.890 --> 00:01:30.110
What would be a typical security of
incident that you may have seen or paharbs

30
00:01:30.110 --> 00:01:33.370
have experienced some of the places
you have been and things you've done.

31
00:01:33.370 --> 00:01:38.760
>> A lot of them tend to revolve
around authorize access of a resource.

32
00:01:38.760 --> 00:01:41.400
People like to go sniffing around,
see what they can find,

33
00:01:41.400 --> 00:01:45.320
what can they get ahold of, and that
usually trips an alarm for us to go hey,

34
00:01:45.320 --> 00:01:46.540
you're not supposed to be going there.

35
00:01:46.540 --> 00:01:48.510
So that's always been a big one.

36
00:01:48.510 --> 00:01:51.530
Even physical access as well,
people get snoopy and

37
00:01:51.530 --> 00:01:54.420
they wanna see what's
behind those closed doors.

38
00:01:54.420 --> 00:01:55.700
All of a sudden you
find somebody who's not

39
00:01:55.700 --> 00:01:59.290
authorized to be in an area of
the building that they are currently in.

40
00:01:59.290 --> 00:02:01.740
You have to let them know,
okay, you can't go here.

41
00:02:01.740 --> 00:02:03.900
How did you get through this by the way?

42
00:02:03.900 --> 00:02:06.790
Try to figure out how that went down and
then fix the security measures so

43
00:02:06.790 --> 00:02:08.720
that they can't be repeated.

44
00:02:08.720 --> 00:02:11.870
>> Okay, so essentially either
somebody winds up in a place where

45
00:02:11.870 --> 00:02:14.630
they're not supposed to be
>> Perhaps on purpose, hopefully not.

46
00:02:14.630 --> 00:02:16.810
Hopefully they're not looking
to do this on purpose.

47
00:02:16.810 --> 00:02:18.590
But whether they got there on purpose,

48
00:02:18.590 --> 00:02:21.970
or just by accident the door was open,
maybe they were curious.

49
00:02:21.970 --> 00:02:24.060
Hey, I've always wanted to
know what's behind that door.

50
00:02:24.060 --> 00:02:26.860
Never had the opportunity, now it's open,
let me go and take a look.

51
00:02:26.860 --> 00:02:32.270
But somehow, some way, we wind up with
either a person, or a group of people,

52
00:02:32.270 --> 00:02:35.330
perhaps, engaging activities that
lead to potential compromise.

53
00:02:35.330 --> 00:02:37.600
Maybe the exposure of information.

54
00:02:37.600 --> 00:02:41.640
Perhaps the exposure of
some confidentiality and/or

55
00:02:41.640 --> 00:02:44.270
a breach of integrity along the way,
and we'll talk about those terms and

56
00:02:44.270 --> 00:02:46.530
what they are as we get into
our conversations here.

57
00:02:46.530 --> 00:02:51.500
But, if we start with a base line of an
incident being an event of some kind that

58
00:02:51.500 --> 00:02:55.640
leads to an unwanted, un-looked for,
undesired outcome, and we add in computer

59
00:02:55.640 --> 00:02:59.350
and security to that mix, and we think
about computer security incidents being

60
00:02:59.350 --> 00:03:04.730
incidents that lead to unwanted outcomes,
but have negative consequences.

61
00:03:04.730 --> 00:03:06.960
And usually from our perspective,

62
00:03:06.960 --> 00:03:11.470
are gonna happen because of somebody
violating security controls.

63
00:03:11.470 --> 00:03:14.880
We begin to be able to think
about the broad expanse.

64
00:03:14.880 --> 00:03:18.800
The broad thought process of what
we may be looking to engage.

65
00:03:18.800 --> 00:03:21.700
And as potentially incident handlers,
and as people,

66
00:03:21.700 --> 00:03:24.250
security professionals, IT professionals,

67
00:03:24.250 --> 00:03:27.800
that are looking ultimately to figure
out how to deal with these issues.

68
00:03:27.800 --> 00:03:31.310
We have to constantly be
thinking about is that activity?

69
00:03:31.310 --> 00:03:32.630
Is that thought process?

70
00:03:32.630 --> 00:03:37.260
Is that activity that somebody's engaging
in, authorized or not, as Daniel said?

71
00:03:37.260 --> 00:03:41.010
Were they able to walk into this area
without credentials and if so, why?

72
00:03:41.010 --> 00:03:44.549
And one of the most important things
we have to think about when it comes to

73
00:03:44.549 --> 00:03:47.580
incident handling is this idea
of can we get to the root cause?

74
00:03:47.580 --> 00:03:49.540
We're going to keep
coming back to this and

75
00:03:49.540 --> 00:03:51.980
thinking about this from a lot
of different perspectives.

76
00:03:51.980 --> 00:03:55.780
We'll talk a little bit later on in some
of our other discussions about risk and

77
00:03:55.780 --> 00:03:57.870
the impact of risk and why it's so

78
00:03:57.870 --> 00:04:01.160
important to understand how to
not only qualify and quantify.

79
00:04:01.160 --> 00:04:05.460
Measure risk, but also understand what's
at the heart of the risk behavior that

80
00:04:05.460 --> 00:04:09.580
we're seeing, engaging in some cases,
or at least trying to avoid in others.

81
00:04:09.580 --> 00:04:13.310
And so root cause, root cause analysis
becomes very, very important as well.

82
00:04:13.310 --> 00:04:16.370
And we have to be thinking,
about how we get to root cause.

83
00:04:16.370 --> 00:04:20.680
How do we understand the events that led
that person to be in that hallway or

84
00:04:20.680 --> 00:04:24.240
in that room or whatever it is, whatever
the situation is that we're talking about,

85
00:04:24.240 --> 00:04:26.260
the one Daniel described as one of many.

86
00:04:27.390 --> 00:04:31.380
How did I sit down at my computer,
open up a share or

87
00:04:31.380 --> 00:04:34.480
an access to a share that I
wasn't supposed to see and

88
00:04:34.480 --> 00:04:37.930
look at a spreadsheet that has
confidential contact information?

89
00:04:37.930 --> 00:04:40.990
I have these conversations
with customers all the time.

90
00:04:40.990 --> 00:04:44.730
I spend a lot of time in the field
auditing work or doing audit work for

91
00:04:44.730 --> 00:04:45.480
customers.

92
00:04:45.480 --> 00:04:48.180
I spend a lot of time configuring
managing, setting up and

93
00:04:48.180 --> 00:04:51.420
building infrastructure for
customers, and I spend a lot of time

94
00:04:51.420 --> 00:04:55.570
helping them to understand how to do those
things in a secure and thoughtful way.

95
00:04:55.570 --> 00:04:59.110
And when breaches occur, and they will
occur, it's only a matter of time,

96
00:04:59.110 --> 00:05:02.390
we have to be thinking about what
could we have done differently.

97
00:05:02.390 --> 00:05:05.970
But not because we wanna assess and
lay blame at the feet of somebody.

98
00:05:05.970 --> 00:05:08.140
This is often one of the things
you have to coach, or

99
00:05:08.140 --> 00:05:11.080
work people through,
when we do this kind of work,

100
00:05:11.080 --> 00:05:14.830
and we show up after the fact,
and we then respond to incidents.

101
00:05:14.830 --> 00:05:18.677
Incident handling is about understanding
and documenting, and detailing, and

102
00:05:18.677 --> 00:05:22.132
ultimately telling the story of what
went on, what led us from hey this was

103
00:05:22.132 --> 00:05:24.861
a wonderful day,
look at how cool things are going to wow,

104
00:05:24.861 --> 00:05:27.007
couldn't have gotten
any worse if we tried.

105
00:05:27.007 --> 00:05:30.913
And how do we walk through the story that
takes us from Point A to Point B, and

106
00:05:30.913 --> 00:05:34.943
what were the key milestones, the touch
points on the way, that occurred and

107
00:05:34.943 --> 00:05:37.733
instead of going the right way,
went the wrong way and

108
00:05:37.733 --> 00:05:41.910
compounded themselves over time into
activities that led to compromise.

109
00:05:41.910 --> 00:05:44.260
We have to tell that story,
tell it authoritatively.

110
00:05:44.260 --> 00:05:47.880
Not be scared and
not be afraid to describe it.

111
00:05:47.880 --> 00:05:50.920
But we also have to understand that
it's not about laying blame at

112
00:05:50.920 --> 00:05:53.770
the feet of the person or the entity or

113
00:05:53.770 --> 00:05:57.310
the combination of those things that led
to the compromise first and foremost.

114
00:05:57.310 --> 00:05:59.520
It may very well be at
some point about blame.

115
00:05:59.520 --> 00:06:02.390
There may be culpability,
there may be blame to go around

116
00:06:02.390 --> 00:06:05.410
People may have acted incorrectly,
hopefully, not on purpose.

117
00:06:05.410 --> 00:06:09.460
But even accidentally, we still may
need to ascribe blame to them and

118
00:06:09.460 --> 00:06:10.260
hold them accountable and

119
00:06:10.260 --> 00:06:13.760
responsible so we could figure out
what to do differently the next time.

120
00:06:13.760 --> 00:06:15.420
But whether that's the ultimate outcome or

121
00:06:15.420 --> 00:06:19.470
not, it's our job as first responders
ultimately as incident responders.

122
00:06:19.470 --> 00:06:21.690
To be able to tell
the story authoritatively.

123
00:06:21.690 --> 00:06:25.090
And to tell it from the perspective
of understanding and

124
00:06:25.090 --> 00:06:29.370
uncovering as much information as we can
to validate that the story is legitimate.

125
00:06:29.370 --> 00:06:32.960
We're not looking, in other words
first and foremost, to say aha, right?

126
00:06:32.960 --> 00:06:36.260
That aha moment that you hear about and
we see in all these detective movies.

127
00:06:36.260 --> 00:06:39.100
It was so and so, right,
doing this this way.

128
00:06:39.100 --> 00:06:39.960
Yeah, that's important.

129
00:06:39.960 --> 00:06:41.049
We wanna be able to get there.

130
00:06:42.180 --> 00:06:44.490
But I will often tell customers
when I do this kind of work for

131
00:06:44.490 --> 00:06:48.150
them, it's as much about being able
to understand the mechanics and

132
00:06:48.150 --> 00:06:52.880
the methodical steps that took place to
get us here as it is about understanding

133
00:06:52.880 --> 00:06:55.570
the who, as opposed to simply the what,
the when, the where.

134
00:06:55.570 --> 00:06:57.490
And we've got to combine
those things together.

135
00:06:57.490 --> 00:07:00.780
So as we begin our conversations, I want
to make sure you're comfortable with this

136
00:07:00.780 --> 00:07:04.840
idea because what we don't want you to
think about incident handling Is that is

137
00:07:04.840 --> 00:07:09.060
ultimately just simply pointing the finger
at somebody because while that's important

138
00:07:09.060 --> 00:07:12.450
that's not gonna solve the problem that
ultimately led to the breach in the first

139
00:07:12.450 --> 00:07:15.260
place and while that particular activity,
that behavior and

140
00:07:15.260 --> 00:07:19.830
that person may not repeat because
you've taken steps to prevent it.

141
00:07:19.830 --> 00:07:23.220
If we don't truly understand what led
to the breach, the weaknesses that

142
00:07:23.220 --> 00:07:27.380
we call vulnerability, and the threats,
the potential to do harm and

143
00:07:27.380 --> 00:07:31.900
the risk, the aggregation of those things,
and the likelihood that they will occur

144
00:07:31.900 --> 00:07:33.930
are still there in the system
in one way or another, right?

00:29:00.250 --> 00:29:02.010
you gotta be willing expose that.

600
00:29:02.010 --> 00:29:05.390
But this is the trick, and this is
what I tell customers all the time.

601
00:29:05.390 --> 00:29:07.080
I'm gonna tell you some things
you don't wanna hear and

602
00:29:07.080 --> 00:29:08.490
show you things you don't wanna see.

603
00:29:08.490 --> 00:29:10.028
But, at the end of that discussion,

604
00:29:10.028 --> 00:29:12.568
I'm gonna show you how to make
sure they never happen again.

605
00:29:12.568 --> 00:29:16.823
And I'm out here to help you make sure
that the bad things that happen dont keep

606
00:29:16.823 --> 00:29:19.620
happening for
the reasons that they happen.

607
00:29:19.620 --> 00:29:21.670
I'm not here to make all
your pain go away and

608
00:29:21.670 --> 00:29:24.010
I'm not here to tell you you're
never gonna have a problem again.

609
00:29:24.010 --> 00:29:26.280
Somebody else is gonna come along,
do something else bad to you,

610
00:29:26.280 --> 00:29:27.250
I promise you that.

611
00:29:27.250 --> 00:29:28.200
But, it's not gonna be for

612
00:29:28.200 --> 00:29:31.720
the same reasons we're talking about now,
if you're willing to be honest and

613
00:29:31.720 --> 00:29:35.470
open with me, and you're willing to
take the outcome of our conversation and

614
00:29:35.470 --> 00:29:38.690
create actionable to-do's that will
ultimately lead to better outcomes.

615
00:29:38.690 --> 00:29:40.420
But it's an incremental game, right?

616
00:29:40.420 --> 00:29:44.300
For every two steps we take forward,
we take three steps back in this business,

617
00:29:44.300 --> 00:29:47.330
and we've gotta constantly
be willing to understand.

618
00:29:47.330 --> 00:29:50.540
I've seen some handlers as security
professionals, generically.

619
00:29:50.540 --> 00:29:56.490
We stand on the front lines and it's our
job to make sure that the same silly and

620
00:29:56.490 --> 00:29:59.020
stupid activities don't lead
to the same mistakes over and

621
00:29:59.020 --> 00:30:02.400
over again, because we get smarter and
better at what we do over time.

622
00:30:02.400 --> 00:30:06.980
And if we're willing to face that reality,
undertake that responsibility and

623
00:30:06.980 --> 00:30:09.670
act accordingly, ourselves,
our customer, and

624
00:30:09.670 --> 00:30:12.210
everybody around us will be the better for
it.

625
00:30:12.210 --> 00:30:14.743
But, this is what it means
to be an handler ultimately.

626
00:30:14.743 --> 00:30:17.490
And this is the responsibility you
have to be willing to take on.

627
00:30:17.490 --> 00:30:20.080
Otherwise, that could teach you how to
make the perfect cup of espresso which is

628
00:30:20.080 --> 00:30:21.880
also an equally great outcome.

629
00:30:21.880 --> 00:30:24.875
If you know anything about me, you know
how passionate I am about espresso, but

630
00:30:24.875 --> 00:30:26.262
that is for another conversation and

631
00:30:26.262 --> 00:30:28.740
for another time good sir 'cuz I
think our clock has ticked down.

632
00:30:28.740 --> 00:30:30.504
>> All right,
our clock has ticked down, but

633
00:30:30.504 --> 00:30:32.770
Adam you were dropping some
serious truth bombs on us.

634
00:30:32.770 --> 00:30:33.376
We have to.

635
00:30:33.376 --> 00:30:35.120
>> TBs.
>> Understand it, that's right, TBs.

636
00:30:35.120 --> 00:30:35.880
>> Not FBs.

637
00:30:35.880 --> 00:30:36.508
>> Not FBs.
>> TBs.

638
00:30:36.508 --> 00:30:37.243
>> That's right.
>> Truth bombs.

639
00:30:37.243 --> 00:30:37.745
>> Truth bombs.

640
00:30:37.745 --> 00:30:39.310
>> Okay, and
we all understand this, right?

641
00:30:39.310 --> 00:30:40.660
That's gonna be part of the job.

642
00:30:40.660 --> 00:30:43.420
It's not just knowing facts and
figures about, security and

643
00:30:43.420 --> 00:30:47.320
handling an incident when someone happens,
and what to do and the steps to take.

644
00:30:47.320 --> 00:30:50.780
It's working with the people
that maybe have caused this,

645
00:30:50.780 --> 00:30:53.480
maybe it was their fault, and you have
to deal with them and let them know,

646
00:30:53.480 --> 00:30:56.560
hey, it was this thing
that you did specifically.

647
00:30:56.560 --> 00:30:58.450
And, that can be a hard
conversation to have.

648
00:30:58.450 --> 00:31:01.080
So, if you don't have
the intestinal fortitude,

649
00:31:01.080 --> 00:31:03.650
as it were, you might wanna get you some

650
00:31:03.650 --> 00:31:07.620
because that day is a coming if this is
the line of work you're gonna get into.

651
00:31:07.620 --> 00:31:10.200
And Adam, you did a great
job of explaining that, and

652
00:31:10.200 --> 00:31:12.320
putting it right out there
at the very beginning so

653
00:31:12.320 --> 00:31:15.580
we have no misunderstandings

654
00:31:15.580 --> 00:31:17.410
But you're right,

655
00:31:17.410 --> 00:31:20.050
We're gonna have to continue
this conversation in a part two.

656
00:31:20.050 --> 00:31:22.000
Hopefully, we'll see
you good people there.

657
00:31:22.000 --> 00:31:22.900
Adam, thanks for joining us.

658
00:31:22.900 --> 00:31:24.330
And we do thank you for watching.

659
00:31:24.330 --> 00:31:27.440
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

660
00:31:27.440 --> 00:31:28.030

They pick back up by defining terms such as Information Owner/System/Custodian/Warfare, the CIA triad (Confidentiality/Integrity/Availability), and Risk assessment.

WEBVTT

7

I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

in today's episode we're back with

9

>> Tremendously awesome,
even better than awesome.

18

The best day ever of Sponge Bob let's say.

19

[LAUGH] Anyway, we're here to talk
some more about incident handling.

20
00:00:43.150 --> 00:00:45.110
We're going to pick up our
conversation where we left off.

21
00:00:45.110 --> 00:00:47.930
We were talking in our last discussion

22
00:00:47.930 --> 00:00:49.720
about some of the background
thought processes.

23
00:00:49.720 --> 00:00:52.550
We talked about the importance
of root cause analysis, spoke

24
00:00:52.550 --> 00:00:55.460
about the importance of understanding
how to have the accountability and

25
00:00:55.460 --> 00:00:59.340
responsibility conversation with
the people that you are working with.

26
00:00:59.340 --> 00:01:01.000
And we defined some basic terms.

27
00:01:01.000 --> 00:01:05.620
Talked about assets, talked about how to
classify data, how important things are in

28
00:01:05.620 --> 00:01:08.440
understanding that importance with
regards to incident handling.

29
00:01:08.440 --> 00:01:11.200
But we have to build on that knowledge
as Daniel was suggesting and

30
00:01:11.200 --> 00:01:14.560
add some more information and
depth to our conversation.

31
00:01:14.560 --> 00:01:16.830
So let's talk about some
common terminology.

32
00:01:16.830 --> 00:01:21.000
We have the concepts of information
systems, data ownership and

33
00:01:21.000 --> 00:01:22.140
data custodianship.

34
00:01:22.140 --> 00:01:24.950
For information ownership,
information custodianship,

35
00:01:24.950 --> 00:01:26.360
you can view them either way.

36
00:01:26.360 --> 00:01:27.620
I mentioned data ownership and

37
00:01:27.620 --> 00:01:32.540
custodianship in the bottom conversation
and passing just as common on the side,

38
00:01:32.540 --> 00:01:34.960
but we didn't wanna go on
the detail of what they represent.

39
00:01:34.960 --> 00:01:37.460
So, I want to make sure we're
comfortable with these terms.

40
00:01:37.460 --> 00:01:41.720
Vocabulary is so important to what
we do in information security.

41
00:01:41.720 --> 00:01:43.460
Understanding the baseline or

42
00:01:43.460 --> 00:01:47.260
the general thought process that we
engage in as part of a dialogue.

43
00:01:47.260 --> 00:01:49.580
Making sure everybody is on the same page.

44
00:01:49.580 --> 00:01:53.740
And that we are speaking the same language
and meaning the same things when we speak

45
00:01:53.740 --> 00:01:57.720
about those terms is very
important criteria for success.

46
00:01:57.720 --> 00:02:01.510
And so information system,
sometimes referred to as the ISMS,

47
00:02:01.510 --> 00:02:03.620
the Information Security
Management System,

48
00:02:03.620 --> 00:02:07.870
but generically the IS, the information
system, is the computer, or

49
00:02:07.870 --> 00:02:12.070
the targeted system that we are going to
be looking at, managing, interacting with.

50
00:02:12.070 --> 00:02:15.350
In this case, with regards to
instant handling, examining, and

51
00:02:15.350 --> 00:02:18.310
most likely doing some sort
of triage with, right?

52
00:02:18.310 --> 00:02:23.210
It's the system that modifies raw data,
creates it, manipulates it, manages it,

53
00:02:23.210 --> 00:02:27.420
stores it, uses it, presents it, etcetera,
all of the activities we would think

54
00:02:27.420 --> 00:02:32.540
about, and allows users to interact
with that data in one or more

55
00:02:32.540 --> 00:02:36.320
ways with regards to whatever it is that
they need to do to accomplish their jobs.

56
00:02:36.320 --> 00:02:39.780
All of us, in other words, use
information systems on a regular basis.

57
00:02:39.780 --> 00:02:42.340
We all have computers or mobile devices or

58
00:02:42.340 --> 00:02:45.550
some sort of electronic device
that accesses data today.

59
00:02:45.550 --> 00:02:46.676
Probably more than one.

60
00:02:46.676 --> 00:02:49.050
I have a tablet, I have a laptop,

61
00:02:49.050 --> 00:02:52.020
I have two laptops sitting on
the desk here in front of me.

62
00:02:52.020 --> 00:02:55.610
I have a smart phone, although most people
make fun of if because it's a Blackberry,

63
00:02:55.610 --> 00:02:57.500
but it is still a good
phone none the less.

64
00:02:57.500 --> 00:02:59.940
It's a more intelligent phone
than most people realize.

65
00:02:59.940 --> 00:03:03.260
Although, these days, with all the
problems going on with my older version,

66
00:03:03.260 --> 00:03:06.160
I can no longer run almost any
of the apps that I did have.

67
00:03:06.160 --> 00:03:08.790
The small number of apps that I
did have on it no longer work.

68
00:03:08.790 --> 00:03:11.430
As we make our change over to
the Android operating system.

69
00:03:11.430 --> 00:03:13.870
But nonetheless, it is a smart phone.

70
00:03:13.870 --> 00:03:17.780
And any of these devices, all of them are
information systems in one way or another.

71
00:03:17.780 --> 00:03:20.950
I can create, interact with,
modify, consume, use, and

72
00:03:20.950 --> 00:03:22.340
manipulate data using them.

73
00:03:22.340 --> 00:03:25.550
That's definition of
an information system.

74
00:03:25.550 --> 00:03:28.650
It allows us to share and
process information and

75
00:03:28.650 --> 00:03:30.690
to interact with it in one or more ways.

76
00:03:30.690 --> 00:03:36.350
Information ownership, data ownership is
about the creation of that information.

77
00:03:36.350 --> 00:03:41.100
We classify owners as the people
that are data creating

78
00:03:41.100 --> 00:03:43.170
information in one form or another.

79
00:03:43.170 --> 00:03:47.470
And then are going to ultimately have the
final say as to who gets to access that

80
00:03:47.470 --> 00:03:50.860
data under what conditions and
to what end or for what purpose.

81
00:03:50.860 --> 00:03:54.270
And so ownership is all about
understanding that, number one,

82
00:03:54.270 --> 00:03:57.540
it's the first and most important
criteria, you have created something.

83
00:03:57.540 --> 00:04:00.880
And then number two, that you have rights
to then decide from an information

84
00:04:00.880 --> 00:04:05.390
management and account control
perspective, access control, who will or

85
00:04:05.390 --> 00:04:07.370
will not be given rights to that data.

86
00:04:07.370 --> 00:04:10.570
Ownership implies final
decision making authority,

87
00:04:10.570 --> 00:04:13.780
whereas custodianship is the role or

88
00:04:13.780 --> 00:04:19.080
the act of implementing the access control
thoughts and requirements from owners.

89
00:04:19.080 --> 00:04:23.150
So if an owner says to me, I would like
Adam to be able to have this level of

90
00:04:23.150 --> 00:04:27.800
access and Daniel to have that level of
access, the custodian has to go out and

91
00:04:27.800 --> 00:04:32.240
implement that system, and then monitor
the data and ensure that Adam and

92
00:04:32.240 --> 00:04:35.240
Daniel both have rights to
whatever specification or

93
00:04:35.240 --> 00:04:38.540
level the owner has actually laid out for
us.

94
00:04:38.540 --> 00:04:43.140
So custodianship is about the interaction,
the day to day oversight and

95
00:04:43.140 --> 00:04:47.130
management of data, whereas
ownership is about the creation and

96
00:04:47.130 --> 00:04:51.450
the overarching responsibility for
that data in the organization from

97
00:04:51.450 --> 00:04:56.822
a governance perspective as well as from
a axis control perspective, ultimately.

98
00:04:56.822 --> 00:05:00.480
Want to make sure we differentiate between
these roles, because it's very important

99
00:05:00.480 --> 00:05:04.610
to know that there ultimately
typically is one owner for data.

100
00:05:04.610 --> 00:05:08.430
And there may by more than one custodian,
depending on where data lives, and

101
00:05:08.430 --> 00:05:12.280
in how many systems that data may or
may not be accessible through.

102
00:05:12.280 --> 00:05:15.330
And I'm not talking about end users
that consume data, I'm talking about

103
00:05:15.330 --> 00:05:19.050
the custodians that interact with data,
to manage and to oversee it,

104
00:05:19.050 --> 00:05:22.750
because if the data is stored in
multiple places through replication or

105
00:05:22.750 --> 00:05:26.260
some sort of cloud-based
distribution technology,

106
00:05:26.260 --> 00:05:30.730
there may be multiple administrators that
act essentially in the role of custodian.

107
00:05:30.730 --> 00:05:32.770
And we have to keep that in mind,
and think about that, and

108
00:05:32.770 --> 00:05:33.830
understand that as well.

109
00:05:33.830 --> 00:05:35.880
So, it is something just to bear in mind.

110
00:05:35.880 --> 00:05:38.740
But we want to make sure we have a good,
formal,

111
00:05:38.740 --> 00:05:41.280
thorough understanding of
the definitions of these terms,

112
00:05:41.280 --> 00:05:44.170
from the vocabulary perspective
they are very important.

113
00:05:44.170 --> 00:05:45.170
I speak of vocabulary and

114
00:05:45.170 --> 00:05:47.740
I thinks they're important,
what about the information warfare?

115
00:05:47.740 --> 00:05:50.365
A topic we hear so much about these days.

116
00:05:50.365 --> 00:05:53.365
Although we hear the discussions about so
many different ways.

117
00:05:53.365 --> 00:05:56.360
We hear cyber war, cyber warfare.

118
00:05:56.360 --> 00:06:00.530
We hear all sort of stories about things
that have going on, either between one or

119
00:06:00.530 --> 00:06:04.990
more countries, or between actors
representing those countries proxies, and

120
00:06:04.990 --> 00:06:09.530
this term is often used and misused very,
very liberally these days, but

121
00:06:09.530 --> 00:06:14.200
generically, the idea of information
warfare is the idea of using

122
00:06:14.200 --> 00:06:19.360
computers and work Information systems
to be able to execute attacks or

123
00:06:19.360 --> 00:06:23.740
somehow execute access illegally and
against the policies and

124
00:06:23.740 --> 00:06:26.870
procedures in place on those
systems against other systems.

125
00:06:26.870 --> 00:06:29.670
In other words, traditionally what
we would define as hacking, right?

126
00:06:29.670 --> 00:06:31.950
And the idea of cyber warfare or

127
00:06:31.950 --> 00:06:35.770
information warfare is really
the fundamental idea of being able to use

128
00:06:35.770 --> 00:06:39.710
information systems to attack
other information systems.

129
00:06:39.710 --> 00:06:44.390
And the actors that are doing so are cyber
warriors, people we often hear about and

130
00:06:44.390 --> 00:06:45.620
talk a lot about today.

131
00:06:45.620 --> 00:06:48.540
When you are defending your
systems against others,

132
00:06:48.540 --> 00:06:50.305
you're acting in a defensive role.

133
00:06:50.305 --> 00:06:53.675
When you are engaging this activity
offensively against others,

134
00:06:53.675 --> 00:06:55.785
you're acting in an offensive manner.

135
00:06:55.785 --> 00:06:59.765
Hackers may be deployed on both ends
of that spectrum, ethical hackers,

136
00:06:59.765 --> 00:07:03.505
as we've certainly spoken about in
other courses and other conversations,

137
00:07:03.505 --> 00:07:08.725
are acting, usually on the defensive side
to prevent those attacks, where as hackers

138
00:07:08.725 --> 00:07:12.610
that act in bad faith, that are out
probably for fun and profit, most likely.

139
00:07:12.610 --> 00:07:15.790
Are acting on the offensive side
to see if they can break in.

140
00:07:15.790 --> 00:07:17.950
Both sets of activities
have to be monitored and

141
00:07:17.950 --> 00:07:21.170
looked at closely by incident handlers,
because we have to be aware of

142
00:07:21.170 --> 00:07:24.460
what activities are taking place in
order to better understand the story and

143
00:07:24.460 --> 00:07:27.560
the scope of whatever we may
be asked to investigate.

144
00:07:27.560 --> 00:07:30.490
And we may not know on the surface
whether it was a friendly or

145
00:07:30.490 --> 00:07:32.620
an unfriendly act that we're
being asked to investigate.

146
00:07:32.620 --> 00:07:35.300
And so we get in and
start moving around a little bit and

147
00:07:35.300 --> 00:07:36.680
understanding what's been going on.

148
00:07:36.680 --> 00:07:40.767
There are many instances in my career
over the many years I've been doing this,

149
00:07:40.767 --> 00:07:45.038
many decades that I've been doing this,
that I've been asked to investigate some

150
00:07:45.038 --> 00:07:48.718
sort of an event or undertake
an investigation on behalf of a customer.

151
00:07:48.718 --> 00:07:52.970
And it turns out that a lot of the time
it certainly is nefarious activity.

152
00:07:52.970 --> 00:07:56.516
It is somebody being up to no good and
we clearly identify that.

153
00:07:56.516 --> 00:08:00.272
Much rarer and off in the corner
as a business case, as it were.

154
00:08:00.272 --> 00:08:04.229
But occasionally, we find evidence of the
fact that these are activities that were

155
00:08:04.229 --> 00:08:08.210
engaged in legitimately by the legitimate
actors inside the organization.

156
00:08:08.210 --> 00:08:11.260
But because their activities
were not properly documented,

157
00:08:11.260 --> 00:08:14.820
they perhaps didn't follow the proper
change management procedures.

158
00:08:14.820 --> 00:08:18.822
Maybe they didn't notify the appropriate
people or take those activities during

159
00:08:18.822 --> 00:08:22.476
normal maintenance windows, or you know
whatever the case may be that they

160
00:08:22.476 --> 00:08:26.550
would normally do in order to prevent this
kind of activity from raising red flags.

161
00:08:26.550 --> 00:08:30.168
And as a result we are sometimes
diagnosing activities that prove to be

162

we wanna have a forensically

safeguard is part of the outcome of

topics.title: Introduction to Incident Response and Handling

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam start their discussion about Risk and Risk Management with regards to Incident Response/Handling. They begin by defining Risk, examining 2 common formulas for calculating Risk. Then they describe the 7 steps involved in Risk Management and look at some resources to help you get your finger on the pulse of Risk in context of Incident Response.

>> [LAUGH]
>> May be familiar with them depending on

574
00:27:15.319 --> 00:27:15.958
where you live.

575
00:27:15.958 --> 00:27:18.176
We have the equivalent of
them all over the world.

576
00:27:18.176 --> 00:27:21.797
We typhoons, and cyclones, and all sorts
of stuff that are gonna be named for

577
00:27:21.797 --> 00:27:22.925
these kinds of storms.

578
00:27:22.925 --> 00:27:25.142
Nor'easters up in the northeast,
same idea.

579
00:27:25.142 --> 00:27:25.910
I think our name is the coolest,

580
00:27:25.910 --> 00:27:26.585
the hurricane's-
>> Yeah, hurricane.

581
00:27:26.585 --> 00:27:27.669
>> The coolest, rIght?

582
00:27:27.669 --> 00:27:30.973
But, if you live with this kind of
weather event certain times a year,

583
00:27:30.973 --> 00:27:32.716
you know that you have to go outside.

584
00:27:32.716 --> 00:27:35.441
You have to take all the stuff that could
blow around on the yard in if there's

585
00:27:35.441 --> 00:27:36.049
a storm coming.

586
00:27:36.049 --> 00:27:38.481
You have to put up shutters
to protect the windows.

587
00:27:38.481 --> 00:27:40.424
All the kind of stuff you
have to do to minimize or

588
00:27:40.424 --> 00:27:43.449
mitigate the potential liability
associated with the risk of the storm.

589
00:27:43.449 --> 00:27:44.986
Right, so that's the kind of stuff we do.

590
00:27:44.986 --> 00:27:48.361
Transference or transferring of
risk is essentially giving the risk

591
00:27:48.361 --> 00:27:51.830
to somebody else in exchange for
something, typically money.

592
00:27:51.830 --> 00:27:53.996
Classic examples are insurance.

593
00:27:53.996 --> 00:27:56.630
You buy insurance, transferring risk.

594
00:27:56.630 --> 00:28:00.021
Cloud services and essentially
outsourcing, your ability to manage your

595
00:28:00.021 --> 00:28:03.080
infrastructure by paying
somebody to do it on your behalf.

596
00:28:03.080 --> 00:28:06.670
Another classic example of transference
with regards to risk management and

597
00:28:06.670 --> 00:28:07.724
mitigation, right?

598
00:28:07.724 --> 00:28:10.711
I mean, you could view that potentially
either way as a mitigation or

599
00:28:10.711 --> 00:28:11.750
a transference event.

600
00:28:11.750 --> 00:28:15.563
But we tend to classify cloud services as
transference events because essentially

601
00:28:15.563 --> 00:28:19.326
you're handing off infrastructure to
somebody else, asking them to manage it.

602
00:28:19.326 --> 00:28:22.470
And you're paying them on
behalf of the business.

603
00:28:22.470 --> 00:28:24.261
So it's a transference of risk.

604
00:28:24.261 --> 00:28:25.690
They're taking on the liability.

605
00:28:25.690 --> 00:28:29.420
So make sure we understand the strategies
associated with risk management.

606
00:28:29.420 --> 00:28:31.230
Also wanna talk about
cost benefit analysis.

607
00:28:31.230 --> 00:28:33.760
I mentioned it quickly before,
but the understanding of

608
00:28:33.760 --> 00:28:37.880
the value of that countermeasure and
measuring ROI, the return on investment.

609
00:28:37.880 --> 00:28:42.400
To understand what we're getting back with
regards to the investments we make around

610
00:28:42.400 --> 00:28:45.570
the ability to validate controls and
countermeasures and the minimization or

611
00:28:45.570 --> 00:28:46.790
mitigation activities.

612
00:28:46.790 --> 00:28:48.738
Important for
us to engage in those behaviors.

613
00:28:48.738 --> 00:28:52.450
We also wanna think about the ability
to measure residual risk, right?

614
00:28:52.450 --> 00:28:55.737
I've mentioned before that there is
always risk left over in any system,

615
00:28:55.737 --> 00:28:56.700
no matter what we do.

616
00:28:56.700 --> 00:29:00.520
Wanna understand that there's no
such thing as a zero risk solution.

617
00:29:00.520 --> 00:29:04.520
We strive for that, it's that golden light
at the end of the tunnel that we always

618
00:29:04.520 --> 00:29:05.960
move towards, but
we never quite get there.

619
00:29:05.960 --> 00:29:09.159
Because there's always unknown quantities,
always unknown risk, or

620
00:29:09.159 --> 00:29:11.550
risk that goes unmitigated or
unchallenged.

621
00:29:11.550 --> 00:29:13.780
And as a result,
is always inherent in the system.

622
00:29:13.780 --> 00:29:16.080
So wanna think about that.

623
00:29:16.080 --> 00:29:19.422
Again, we could frame that
using a formula of a type.

624
00:29:19.422 --> 00:29:22.806
But you could say residual risk is
essentially equal to inherent risk

625
00:29:22.806 --> 00:29:24.735
multiplied by the control risk.

626
00:29:24.735 --> 00:29:27.740
An inherent risk will be defined
as stretch times vulnerability.

627
00:29:27.740 --> 00:29:32.334
But the reality is, again, it's very hard
to put numbers to that and say, okay, so

628
00:29:32.334 --> 00:29:34.751
as a result my residual risk is two,
right?

629
00:29:34.751 --> 00:29:35.281
>> Yeah.

630
00:29:35.281 --> 00:29:36.839
[LAUGH]
>> Or if you remember Back to School,

631
00:29:36.839 --> 00:29:40.063
at the end where Rodney Dangerfield's
character's sitting there doing

632
00:29:40.063 --> 00:29:40.740
all the exams.

633
00:29:40.740 --> 00:29:43.296
Where he's getting that grilling,
just that huge grilling.

634
00:29:43.296 --> 00:29:46.983
And the Sam Kinison character screaming
at him, going, just answer the question.

635
00:29:46.983 --> 00:29:48.165
And he says, four?

636
00:29:48.165 --> 00:29:50.741
>> [LAUGH]
>> And that's the answer, right?

637
00:29:50.741 --> 00:29:52.296
So it's one of those things, right?

638
00:29:52.296 --> 00:29:53.723
I mean, it's not like that.

639
00:29:53.723 --> 00:29:56.072
It's not that epiphany moment where
the number pops in your head, and you go,

640
00:29:56.072 --> 00:29:57.070
okay, that's it.

641
00:29:57.070 --> 00:29:58.910
This formula, again,
is really just meant for

642
00:29:58.910 --> 00:30:02.260
you to frame the conversation
around the moving parts and

643
00:30:02.260 --> 00:30:07.180
understand how risk is going to be
essentially constituted, right?

644
00:30:07.180 --> 00:30:09.280
What makes up, what are the moving parts?

645
00:30:09.280 --> 00:30:11.270
What are the things we have
understand that make up risk?

646
00:30:11.270 --> 00:30:13.781
Inherent risk times the controls we apply,
and

647
00:30:13.781 --> 00:30:18.170
inherent risk being essentially
a summation of threats and vulnerability.

648
00:30:18.170 --> 00:30:21.600
Is meaning for us to look at our
landscape and assess it and say,

649
00:30:21.600 --> 00:30:23.756
have we accounted for all the threats?

650
00:30:23.756 --> 00:30:25.440
Do we understand all the vulnerabilities?

651
00:30:25.440 --> 00:30:29.600
If we have those things and we have
controls that are supposed to offset them,

652
00:30:29.600 --> 00:30:31.580
how good of a job are we doing there?

653
00:30:31.580 --> 00:30:34.167
And if we're offsetting all of
the risks we've identified,

654
00:30:34.167 --> 00:30:36.520
and we have controls in place,
and they are equitable.

655
00:30:36.520 --> 00:30:38.374
We've done a quantitative analysis and

656
00:30:38.374 --> 00:30:42.138
understand the value of those controls is
positive, then maybe we're on the road

657
00:30:42.138 --> 00:30:45.190
towards understanding how to
deal with risk the right way.

658
00:30:45.190 --> 00:30:47.875
But we have to then understand
that there's always residual risk.

659
00:30:47.875 --> 00:30:52.248
That there are gonna be either threats in
vulnerabilities that have not been clearly

660
00:30:52.248 --> 00:30:56.500
identified, or have been but are not being
mitigated properly cuz the controls in

661
00:30:56.500 --> 00:30:58.550
place are not functioning correctly.

662
00:30:58.550 --> 00:31:01.120
And that's what this formula,
quote unquote,

663
00:31:01.120 --> 00:31:03.850
is supposed to help us to understand and
potentially point us to.

664
00:31:03.850 --> 00:31:05.496
So just to understand that, right?

665
00:31:05.496 --> 00:31:08.712
If we don't reduce risk to the acceptable
level, we have to step back and

666
00:31:08.712 --> 00:31:10.780
go back and iterate through this again.

667
00:31:10.780 --> 00:31:14.890
And understand that there may be
more than one bite at the apple or

668
00:31:14.890 --> 00:31:17.660
time around the wheel that we
have to take to get it right.

669
00:31:17.660 --> 00:31:20.010
Not every control is
applied the right way.

670
00:31:20.010 --> 00:31:22.760
Not every risk is mitigated
the right way the first time.

671
00:31:22.760 --> 00:31:24.430
You may have to do it more
than once to get it right, and

672
00:31:24.430 --> 00:31:26.620
you gotta think about that and
be aware of that.

673
00:31:26.620 --> 00:31:30.560
And finally, with regards to risk and
risk analysis, risk assessment, and

674
00:31:30.560 --> 00:31:33.590
all the things we talked about, wanna
again reference NIST here for a minute.

675
00:31:33.590 --> 00:31:36.060
The NIST approach to controls,
implementation.

676
00:31:36.060 --> 00:31:37.120
How do we implement controls?

677
00:31:37.120 --> 00:31:39.070
Talked a lot about controls and
their value.

678
00:31:39.070 --> 00:31:43.183
Talked about assessing them, analyzing
them, understanding if the ROI is there

679
00:31:43.183 --> 00:31:46.640
through cost benefit analysis and
quantitative risk analysis.

680
00:31:46.640 --> 00:31:48.021
But how do we actually implement them?

681
00:31:48.021 --> 00:31:48.840
What do we do?

682
00:31:48.840 --> 00:31:50.600
Seven step process, right?

683
00:31:50.600 --> 00:31:51.709
Seven step process.

684
00:31:51.709 --> 00:31:53.183
Wanna go through here real quickly.

685
00:31:53.183 --> 00:31:57.922
Wanna prioritize our actions, want to
evaluate recommended control options,

686
00:31:57.922 --> 00:32:01.278
understanding that there may
be more than one solution.

687
00:32:01.278 --> 00:32:02.504
Gotta figure out what the best one is.

688
00:32:02.504 --> 00:32:06.106
Most cost effective, most relevant,
most functional, most appropriate for

689
00:32:06.106 --> 00:32:07.435
the organization.

690
00:32:07.435 --> 00:32:10.250
Gotta conduct the cost benefit
analysis as we talked about.

691
00:32:10.250 --> 00:32:12.630
Select the appropriate
controller controls.

692
00:32:12.630 --> 00:32:14.640
Assign responsibility for them.

693
00:32:14.640 --> 00:32:18.294
Nothing worse than saying I found
the perfect control, it's cost effective,

694
00:32:18.294 --> 00:32:19.240
we can do it.

695
00:32:19.240 --> 00:32:21.829
And then nobody goes ahead and takes
responsibility for it and gets it done.

696
00:32:21.829 --> 00:32:26.020
And then we get hit by the exact threat or
risk that we were talking about.

697
00:32:26.020 --> 00:32:28.450
Everybody stands around afterwards going,
okay whose fault was it?

698
00:32:28.450 --> 00:32:28.990
Well, I don't know.

699
00:32:28.990 --> 00:32:29.663
I didn't do that.

700
00:32:29.663 --> 00:32:30.904
It wasn't me, right?

701
00:32:30.904 --> 00:32:33.740
I'm not the one that had that whole issue,
right?

702
00:32:33.740 --> 00:32:35.082
So I mean, that's what we gotta do.

703
00:32:35.082 --> 00:32:37.112
You don't wanna look at each
other after the fact and say,

704
00:32:37.112 --> 00:32:38.550
I thought you did it, right?

705
00:32:38.550 --> 00:32:39.730
That's never a good conversation.

706
00:32:39.730 --> 00:32:43.780
>> I like doing the whole
[LAUGH] it was that guy.

707
00:32:43.780 --> 00:32:46.250
>> Assign responsibility,
very important right?

708
00:32:46.250 --> 00:32:48.640
So put Daniel's name on the line
next hour whenever we come up.

709
00:32:48.640 --> 00:32:51.635
But that, develop a safeguard and
limitation plan, right?

710
00:32:51.635 --> 00:32:54.864
So have that not just responsibility line,
but actually the plan that says Daniel is

711
00:32:54.864 --> 00:32:57.760
gonna do it, and by the way,
this is what Daniel's gonna do.

712
00:32:57.760 --> 00:32:59.210
And make sure that Daniel does it.

713
00:32:59.210 --> 00:33:03.000
Then implement the selected controls,
actually do what we said we're gonna do.

714
00:33:03.000 --> 00:33:05.820
And although it's not a step
I'll add an eighth step, but

715
00:33:05.820 --> 00:33:09.250
let's be clear, this is Adam adding it,
not NIST saying it.

716
00:33:09.250 --> 00:33:12.150
Go back and spot check in order to
make sure through verification and

717
00:33:12.150 --> 00:33:14.020
validation that it's being done.

718
00:33:14.020 --> 00:33:17.330
We often say inspect what you expect,
right?

719
00:33:17.330 --> 00:33:18.650
Trust but verify.

720
00:33:18.650 --> 00:33:21.950
I would say that in Russian, but
not everybody would understand it.

721
00:33:21.950 --> 00:33:26.410
But the idea is that,
you gotta understand, you gotta know

722
00:33:26.410 --> 00:33:29.360
that what people say they're gonna do,
despite their best efforts, and

723
00:33:29.360 --> 00:33:33.420
despite their trustworthiness, doesn't
always get done for a variety of reasons.

724
00:33:33.420 --> 00:33:38.383
And if you learn nothing else from all of
our time together, learn to be skeptical.

725
00:33:38.383 --> 00:33:42.183
All right, it's one of the most important
tools you put in your toolbox as

726
00:33:42.183 --> 00:33:46.470
a security practitioner, as an IT
professional, as an incident handler.

727
00:33:46.470 --> 00:33:47.880
Question everything around you.

728
00:33:47.880 --> 00:33:52.370
Not because you want to be that person
who is just never ever satisfied.

729
00:33:52.370 --> 00:33:53.550
Quite the opposite.

730
00:33:53.550 --> 00:33:56.360
I'm more than willing to accept
a logical explanation if

731
00:33:56.360 --> 00:33:58.200
somebody offers me one that's plausible.

732
00:33:58.200 --> 00:34:01.060
But I want to see proof of it before
I'm willing to put it down on paper and

733
00:34:01.060 --> 00:34:03.310
sign my name next to it and
say I believe, right?

734
00:34:03.310 --> 00:34:07.330
Because if you can't convince me, then
it's just unlikely that it's occurring

735
00:34:07.330 --> 00:34:10.250
that way, not because I'm
the idiot who says no no no,

736
00:34:10.250 --> 00:34:13.040
but rather I'm the skeptical person
that wants you to show it to me.

737
00:34:13.040 --> 00:34:17.720
And that's what the mentality, the thought
process of risk analysis, risk assessment,

738
00:34:17.720 --> 00:34:20.450
risk management needs to be,
trust but verify.

739
00:34:20.450 --> 00:34:24.284
If I can validate what you're doing and
I can show that it's being done, there's

740
00:34:24.284 --> 00:34:28.361

transcription trail that we I can look at.

741
00:34:28.361 --> 00:34:31.131
I have proof beyond reasonable
doubt that we're doing everything

742
00:34:31.131 --> 00:34:32.420

743
00:34:32.420 --> 00:34:35.840
And that's what we need to have, and
that's where we need to find ourselves

744
00:34:35.840 --> 00:34:39.190

risk with regards to incident handling.

745
00:34:39.190 --> 00:34:42.380

00:34:58.060 --> 00:35:00.110
Looking forward to that,
hopefully you are as well.

755
00:35:00.110 --> 00:35:03.150
But we are out of time for this episode,

00:35:03.150 --> 00:35:07.530

748

749
00:36:10.310 --> 00:36:13.115

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue explaining the process or steps of Incident Response. They jump back in by looking at the details about an Incident Response Plan's creation and implementation. They start down a lengthy list of steps, beginning with Identification, Incident Recording, Initial Response, Communicating the Incident, Containment, Formulating a Response Strategy, Incident Classification, and Incident Investigation.

And, of course,

13

>> Howdy.

>> [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK]

18
00:00:38.480 --> 00:00:40.389
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's talk a little bit about, or

19
00:00:40.389 --> 00:00:44.070
a little bit more, I should say, about
incident handling, incident response.

20
00:00:44.070 --> 00:00:45.502
We're gonna continue our conversation.

21
00:00:45.502 --> 00:00:48.243
Just reminding you,
if you have not seen the prior episode,

22
00:00:48.243 --> 00:00:51.683
definitely important for you to take
a look at that before we jump in here only

23
00:00:51.683 --> 00:00:54.883
cuz you'll kinda miss the thread
of the conversation we're having.

24
00:00:54.883 --> 00:00:58.069
And it may not make as much sense to you
based on what we're about to jump into and

25
00:00:58.069 --> 00:00:59.150
continue talking about.

26
00:00:59.150 --> 00:01:02.410
So we left off talking about
the incident response plan, why it's so

27
00:01:02.410 --> 00:01:06.668
important, what the goals are, why we have
to do the things we do, reasons behind it,

28
00:01:06.668 --> 00:01:07.840
the motivation.

29
00:01:07.840 --> 00:01:10.330
Who executes on that plan,
really is the next question, and

30
00:01:10.330 --> 00:01:13.798
that execution of the plan is left
to the incident response team.

31
00:01:13.798 --> 00:01:17.621
And the incident response team is a group
of very talented individuals made up of

32
00:01:17.621 --> 00:01:21.046
different areas of the company
representing different disciplines,

33
00:01:21.046 --> 00:01:22.543
having different knowledge.

34
00:01:22.543 --> 00:01:26.645
All brought together so that they can be
the experts that will ultimately go out

35
00:01:26.645 --> 00:01:30.010
and figure out how to respond
to whatever's happening.

36
00:01:30.010 --> 00:01:33.070
You know, I think back,
we often talk about movies and TV shows,

37
00:01:33.070 --> 00:01:34.060
things like that.

38
00:01:34.060 --> 00:01:36.734
I think back to Mission Impossible,
the original series,

39
00:01:36.734 --> 00:01:40.531
the TV series from the 1960s, because
you don’t really see this in the movies,

40
00:01:40.531 --> 00:01:43.010
the newer movies,
they don’t just do it the same way.

41
00:01:43.010 --> 00:01:47.946
But in the old TV series, if you remember,
Peter Graves was Mr. Phelps,

42
00:01:47.946 --> 00:01:52.733
and you had Martin Landau and
Barbara Bain, his wife, and everybody.

43
00:01:52.733 --> 00:01:54.430
It was a great show, right?

44
00:01:54.430 --> 00:01:57.390
And you would see in the beginning,
he would go out, and Mr.

45
00:01:57.390 --> 00:02:00.500
Phelps, the character who
kinda coordinates and

46
00:02:00.500 --> 00:02:04.820
plays the incident manager role,
incident coordinator role for the team.

47
00:02:04.820 --> 00:02:08.540
He would go out, get his marching orders,
somewhere in the middle of nowhere, and

48
00:02:08.540 --> 00:02:12.910
then magically afterwards be
transported back to the cool,

49
00:02:12.910 --> 00:02:16.200
hip, 60s bachelor pad somewhere,
right, in the penthouse.

50
00:02:16.200 --> 00:02:18.870
And he'd be sitting around figuring
out who was gonna, essentially,

51
00:02:18.870 --> 00:02:22.730
play a part in that week's episode and
be on the incident team.

52
00:02:22.730 --> 00:02:26.820
And he would go through the portfolio
of all the pictures, of all the people.

53
00:02:26.820 --> 00:02:30.637
And he'd throw the pictures of
the people on the desk, or on the table.

54
00:02:30.637 --> 00:02:34.298
And then the next thing you know,
they would be in the room meeting,

55
00:02:34.298 --> 00:02:37.833
talking about the plan and
how they’re going to essentially take

56
00:02:37.833 --> 00:02:40.749
on the villain or
whoever the subject of the show was.

57
00:02:40.749 --> 00:02:42.365
And forming that team,

58
00:02:42.365 --> 00:02:46.095
choosing your experts based on
the requirements of the mission

59
00:02:46.095 --> 00:02:49.515
is really what the incident response team
is designed to help you to accomplish.

60
00:02:49.515 --> 00:02:50.835
It’s an incident handler.

61
00:02:50.835 --> 00:02:53.725
Are you gonna have the same people on
the incident response team all the time?

62
00:02:53.725 --> 00:02:56.809
You may have a core group of people
that are just gonna always be there.

63
00:02:56.809 --> 00:03:01.795
But can an incident response team be
physical, everybody's in the same place?

64
00:03:01.795 --> 00:03:03.010
Sure, absolutely.

65
00:03:03.010 --> 00:03:06.190
Can it be virtual,
can you have people that call in and

66
00:03:06.190 --> 00:03:09.570
are experts on demand that you
will just access as needed?

67
00:03:09.570 --> 00:03:11.160
Of course.
Can it be a hybrid where you have

68
00:03:11.160 --> 00:03:12.478
the elements of both?

69
00:03:12.478 --> 00:03:15.110
Certain people that are there
present physically all the time,

70
00:03:15.110 --> 00:03:17.500
others that are remote and
maybe on demand?

71
00:03:17.500 --> 00:03:20.040
Absolutely.
Today, there really isn't a right or

72
00:03:20.040 --> 00:03:21.550
wrong way to do this.

73
00:03:21.550 --> 00:03:24.650
The only wrong thing about
forming an incident response team

74
00:03:24.650 --> 00:03:29.390
is not incorporating the necessary skills
required to respond to the incidents.

75
00:03:29.390 --> 00:03:33.955
And not understanding that all areas of
the company need to have representation in

76
00:03:33.955 --> 00:03:35.952
the incident resolution process.

77
00:03:35.952 --> 00:03:38.950
They need to be communicated with,
they need to be represented.

78
00:03:38.950 --> 00:03:42.200
And if the incident involves
that aspect of the business,

79
00:03:42.200 --> 00:03:45.910
you need to have people that understand it
as being the leads and the experts that

80
00:03:45.910 --> 00:03:50.450
will help you to deal with, minimize,
and ultimately address the concerns.

81
00:03:50.450 --> 00:03:54.120
If somebody attacks the HR,
the financial services, and

82
00:03:54.120 --> 00:03:58.330
reporting systems, you don't want the
person that is answering the phones for

83
00:03:58.330 --> 00:04:01.280
the business being the lead on
the incident response team.

84
00:04:01.280 --> 00:04:04.260
Not because they're not gonna add
something of value, quite the opposite.

85
00:04:04.260 --> 00:04:08.600
They're gonna give us valuable insight
into things, but their area of expertise

86
00:04:08.600 --> 00:04:13.040
is not gonna be in the area where those
systems that are being affected lies.

87
00:04:13.040 --> 00:04:18.006
And as a result, they may not be the most
appropriate choice to be on that team,

88
00:04:18.006 --> 00:04:19.752
given the circumstances.

89
00:04:19.752 --> 00:04:22.202
Or as Daniel's reminded
us in other episodes,

90
00:04:22.202 --> 00:04:25.370
the context of the incident
that we're addressing.

91
00:04:25.370 --> 00:04:29.471
And so we need to understand as we start
this conversation that incident response

92
00:04:29.471 --> 00:04:32.063
teams have to be generated,
have to be populated,

93
00:04:32.063 --> 00:04:35.834
based on the contextual needs of
the incident that we're responding to.

94
00:04:35.834 --> 00:04:38.540
It's a very important thought
process when you think about it.

95
00:04:38.540 --> 00:04:43.410
To that end, we have incident response
handling steps that we identify,

96
00:04:43.410 --> 00:04:48.240
that we have documented and that we should
in our incident response manifesto,

97
00:04:48.240 --> 00:04:52.370
our plan, and our guides that we share
with everybody, have detailed out.

98
00:04:52.370 --> 00:04:55.885
There's traditionally 17 steps
that we outline and highlight.

99
00:04:55.885 --> 00:04:59.260
Wanna share them with you, if we can,
using my, let me try that one more time.

100
00:04:59.260 --> 00:05:01.432
If we can-
>> Look at that, that was perfect.

101
00:05:01.432 --> 00:05:03.765
>> Actually, it would be great if
I could do like one of these, and

102
00:05:03.765 --> 00:05:05.064
it would show up because-
>> [LAUGH]

103
00:05:05.064 --> 00:05:06.337
>> Start coming from the top down and

104
00:05:06.337 --> 00:05:09.890
just pop up off to the side, but that's a
whole other conversation for another time.

105
00:05:09.890 --> 00:05:11.230
So let's just quickly take a look.

106
00:05:11.230 --> 00:05:15.615
I thought, since there are so many steps
involved in the process, that I would at

107
00:05:15.615 --> 00:05:19.405
least put a list together for
you on the screen, quickly highlight them.

108
00:05:19.405 --> 00:05:21.155
We're gonna have an in-depth
conversation around them,

109
00:05:21.155 --> 00:05:22.635
go through them in the next few minutes.

110
00:05:22.635 --> 00:05:25.985
But this way, you could see what we're
referring to as we talk about them,

00:05:25.985 --> 00:05:28.895
instead of just trying to keep them all
straight in your head when I rattle five

112
00:05:28.895 --> 00:05:30.995
or ten of them off all at once.

113
00:05:30.995 --> 00:05:33.425
They are obviously gonna be
captured in the show notes.

114
00:05:33.425 --> 00:05:34.960
You'll have an authoritative list.

115
00:05:34.960 --> 00:05:36.410
Daniel's gonna keep me honest about that,

116
00:05:36.410 --> 00:05:39.860
and he's also gonna spell check, just in
case I missed anything along the way.

117
00:05:39.860 --> 00:05:41.660
So Incident Response/Handling Steps.

118
00:05:41.660 --> 00:05:44.860
You could see we start off at
the top with Identification.

119
00:05:44.860 --> 00:05:48.880
Understanding what it is,
do we have an incident?

120
00:05:48.880 --> 00:05:51.079
If we do have an incident,
what kind of incident?

121
00:05:51.079 --> 00:05:53.337
We've talked about that and
why that's important.

122
00:05:53.337 --> 00:05:55.937
Incident Recording, Initial Response,

123
00:05:55.937 --> 00:06:00.290
communicating the incident to all
the people that may be affected.

124
00:06:00.290 --> 00:06:03.990
Containment, building those barriers
that are gonna isolate the systems, and

125
00:06:03.990 --> 00:06:08.350
as a result, allow us to minimize
the damage, or minimize the impact.

126
00:06:08.350 --> 00:06:11.020
Formulating a Response Strategy.

127
00:06:11.020 --> 00:06:11.799
What are we gonna do?

128
00:06:11.799 --> 00:06:12.660
How are we gonna do it?

129
00:06:12.660 --> 00:06:13.600
When am I gonna do it?

130
00:06:13.600 --> 00:06:14.740
Where are we gonna do it?

131
00:06:14.740 --> 00:06:16.350
We're gonna answer those questions.

132
00:06:16.350 --> 00:06:20.620
And remember, we're gonna take the general
response thought-process off the shelf.

133
00:06:20.620 --> 00:06:22.923
But then we have to tailor it,
we have to scope and tailor.

134
00:06:22.923 --> 00:06:27.248
Essentially, narrowly focus it in to
ensure that the things that we're gonna do

135
00:06:27.248 --> 00:06:29.729
are gonna make sense,
given the parameters,

136
00:06:29.729 --> 00:06:33.720
given the context of the situation
we find ourselves addressing.

137
00:06:33.720 --> 00:06:35.160
Incident Classification.

138
00:06:35.160 --> 00:06:36.980
Gotta know what kinda
incident we're dealing with.

139
00:06:36.980 --> 00:06:42.330
Is it a threat actor, a threat source,
a bad actor of some kind that's hacked in?

140
00:06:42.330 --> 00:06:44.440
Is it a self-inflicted wound?

141
00:06:44.440 --> 00:06:47.830
Is it a vulnerability based
on a misconfiguration?

142
00:06:47.830 --> 00:06:50.690
Is it a bad piece of software that's
made its way into the system?

143
00:06:50.690 --> 00:06:51.860
There's all these possibilities.

144
00:06:51.860 --> 00:06:53.770
We've gotta understand what it is.

145
00:06:53.770 --> 00:06:54.940
Incident Investigation.

146
00:06:54.940 --> 00:06:56.420
We gotta start poking around,

147
00:06:56.420 --> 00:07:00.390
start figuring out what it is we're
doing and how we're going to address it.

148
00:07:00.390 --> 00:07:04.846
Data Collection, come up with and
understand how to gather all the pieces of

149
00:07:04.846 --> 00:07:09.161
information and evidence that may be
valuable to help us tell the story and

150
00:07:09.161 --> 00:07:13.356
ultimately, understand how to
respond to this particular incident.

151
00:07:13.356 --> 00:07:16.439
Forensic Analysis, gotta accurately, and

152
00:07:16.439 --> 00:07:20.169
with a very specific set of procedures and
policies and

153
00:07:20.169 --> 00:07:25.293
methodical steps in mind, address
the evidence that we find and collect.

154
00:07:25.293 --> 00:07:29.131
And Data Collection, number 9,
Forensic Analysis, number 10,

155
00:07:29.131 --> 00:07:33.555
Evidence Protection, number 11,
all go together under the general header,

156
00:07:33.555 --> 00:07:37.543
the general banner, general thought
process of forensic procedures.

157
00:07:37.543 --> 00:07:42.513
And forensic investigative procedures are
used to be able to accurately identify,

158
00:07:42.513 --> 00:07:47.133
collect, document, and then work with and
protect that evidence throughout

159
00:07:47.133 --> 00:07:51.410
the life cycle, or the chain of custody,
that we will often talk about.

160
00:07:51.410 --> 00:07:52.600
So we have all that.

161
00:07:52.600 --> 00:07:58.202
Notification of External Agencies If
necessary and appropriate.

162
00:07:58.202 --> 00:07:59.900
If they can add value.

163
00:07:59.900 --> 00:08:03.285
If they need to be notified because
of policy or regulatory compliance.

164
00:08:03.285 --> 00:08:05.780
And/or because they can.

165
00:08:05.780 --> 00:08:06.529
Hello.
>> [LAUGH]

166
00:08:06.529 --> 00:08:08.019
>> And/or because they can.

167
00:08:08.019 --> 00:08:10.705
Hey look, everybody deserves
a rest at a certain point in time.

168
00:08:10.705 --> 00:08:13.567
My machine just decided it was
gonna take one right now, right?

169
00:08:13.567 --> 00:08:16.421
That's what you get for not moving the
mouse around when the screen goes dark.

170
00:08:16.421 --> 00:08:20.749
So, Notifying External Agencies,
if they can add value.

171
00:08:20.749 --> 00:08:21.850
Very important to think about that.

172
00:08:21.850 --> 00:08:25.287
So, for instance,
would you notify the FBI?

173
00:08:25.287 --> 00:08:27.590
Would you notify local law enforcement?

174
00:08:27.590 --> 00:08:33.670
Would you notify a US cert or some sort of
cert based on whatever country you're in?

175
00:08:33.670 --> 00:08:38.246
Would you notify another agency
that may be able to help?

176
00:08:38.246 --> 00:08:39.870
The answer is yes or no.

177
00:08:39.870 --> 00:08:40.931
It's hard to say.

178
00:08:40.931 --> 00:08:44.650
It would depend partially on the policies
you have in place in the business.

179
00:08:44.650 --> 00:08:47.843
It would depend partially on,
as I said, the legalities and

180
00:08:47.843 --> 00:08:52.619
the regulatory issues associated with that
break-in or that incident, whatever it is.

181
00:08:52.619 --> 00:08:54.272
You may not have a choice in other words,
right?

182
00:08:54.272 --> 00:08:56.625
By law,
you may have to notify these parties.

183
00:08:56.625 --> 00:08:57.857
But, you may not.

184
00:08:57.857 --> 00:08:58.880
It really just depends.

185
00:08:58.880 --> 00:09:01.614
So, that's gonna be one of those
things you put an asterisk next to.

186
00:09:01.614 --> 00:09:03.625
You say, it would be good to do that.

187
00:09:03.625 --> 00:09:06.615
But, if there's an option,
are they gonna add value?

188
00:09:06.615 --> 00:09:10.950
Cuz what you don't wanna have happen is
notify these agencies, have them come in

189
00:09:10.950 --> 00:09:15.285
and dramatically complicate and extend
the incident response, and allow you,

190
00:09:15.285 --> 00:09:18.873
unfortunately, not to get back to
normal as quickly as possible.

191
00:09:18.873 --> 00:09:22.070
Because they're doing the things
that they are designed to do, but

192
00:09:22.070 --> 00:09:24.437
as a result are extending
that recovery process.

193
00:09:24.437 --> 00:09:25.307
That would not be a good outcome.

194
00:09:25.307 --> 00:09:26.342
>> The red tape gun comes out.

195
00:09:26.342 --> 00:09:27.222
>> Yeah, exactly, right.

196
00:09:27.222 --> 00:09:28.180
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

197
00:09:28.180 --> 00:09:29.610
>> Let me have five copies of that,

198
00:09:29.610 --> 00:09:33.050
and could you take three days to
generate them for me please, right?

199
00:09:33.050 --> 00:09:37.650
So, then eradication, system recovery, or
systems recovery if there's more than one.

200
00:09:38.790 --> 00:09:40.144
Incident documentation.

201
00:09:40.144 --> 00:09:42.000
Incident damage and cost assessment.

202
00:09:42.000 --> 00:09:46.430
And of course, finally, as we've always
said, review and update response policies.

203
00:09:46.430 --> 00:09:48.500
Go back and figure out,
are lessons learned?

204
00:09:48.500 --> 00:09:53.425
And a reintegration and reiteration of
those lessons into future responses.

205
00:09:53.425 --> 00:09:55.768
So, this is the general thought process,

206
00:09:55.768 --> 00:09:58.965
the high level step-by-step
methodology we engage in.

207
00:09:58.965 --> 00:10:02.407
What we wanna do is drill down a little
bit, talk in more depth about these steps,

208
00:10:02.407 --> 00:10:03.673
break them down a little bit,

209
00:10:03.673 --> 00:10:06.888
understand more about them over the next
few minutes of our conversation.

210
00:10:06.888 --> 00:10:10.189
We're gonna do that, or at least take
an opportunity to do that now with you.

211
00:10:10.189 --> 00:10:13.156
Let's go through, we'll leave this up, and
we'll just kind of talk to it as we go.

212
00:10:13.156 --> 00:10:15.962
That way we can be reminded of
it as we kinda go through and

213
00:10:15.962 --> 00:10:18.015
discuss the various intricacies here.

214
00:10:18.015 --> 00:10:19.806
So, with regards to
instant identification,

215
00:10:19.806 --> 00:10:21.069
what are we thinking about here?

216
00:10:21.069 --> 00:10:24.462
As I indicated, do we actually have
an incident in the first place, right?

217
00:10:24.462 --> 00:10:26.704
So, validating that
an incident has occurred.

218
00:10:26.704 --> 00:10:28.152
Very important to think about that.

219

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore some of the common threats that an Incident Handler might encounter. episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore some of the common threats that an Incident Handler might encounter. Here they discuss how to handle unauthorized access as an incident, exploring what unauthorized access looks like and then how to prepare for those types of attacks. Also covered is inappropriate system usage.
