We gave you a list in the and some common
ones, give you more explanation of them.

611
00:30:36.511 --> 00:30:39.398
Always got to pay attention to that, but
if you 're not comfortable with using

612
00:30:39.398 --> 00:30:42.320
these tools, and you may not be and
there's nothing wrong with that.

613
00:30:42.320 --> 00:30:44.460
Nobody says you have to use these tools.

614
00:30:44.460 --> 00:30:48.900
But I am suggesting to you that you start
practicing with tools in these categories,

615
00:30:48.900 --> 00:30:51.666
whichever ones you may feel
most comfortable with.

616
00:30:51.666 --> 00:30:55.143
And get to know them, understand them,
understand how they work,

617
00:30:55.143 --> 00:30:57.339
understand the logic of why they work, and

618
00:30:57.339 --> 00:31:01.200
understand how to use them to your
advantage as an incident responder.

619
00:31:01.200 --> 00:31:03.105
That is gonna be very
valuable information for you.

620
00:31:03.105 --> 00:31:05.570
>> Exactly right,
Adam hits the nail right on the head.

621
00:31:05.570 --> 00:31:10.170
You have to build up a repertoire like he
said, maybe not these tools specifically,

622
00:31:10.170 --> 00:31:13.280
but at least inside of their
categories in which they are used.

623
00:31:13.280 --> 00:31:16.860
Of course, the ones we're showing you
are probably the most commonly used ones.

624
00:31:16.860 --> 00:31:19.800
So it probably wouldn't hurt
you to download, install,

625
00:31:19.800 --> 00:31:21.820
play with and start working with this.

626
00:31:21.820 --> 00:31:24.390
You can scan your own machine
all day long and no one cares,

627
00:31:24.390 --> 00:31:26.560
no one's are gonna throw you in jail for
that.

628
00:31:26.560 --> 00:31:29.130
So practice on your own machines,
maybe build a small virtual lab.

629
00:31:29.130 --> 00:31:31.869
You've got some spare laptops or
something laying around,

630
00:31:31.869 --> 00:31:33.650
you can play with this stuff.

631
00:31:33.650 --> 00:31:34.980
And don't forget, read the manual.

632
00:31:34.980 --> 00:31:38.680
I kind of made a joke about
the output being very verbose.

633
00:31:38.680 --> 00:31:41.940
Yeah, it is, and the manuals tend
to be very long and complex.

634
00:31:41.940 --> 00:31:47.140
But if you even grasp 10% of it, 50% of
it, you are a force to be reckoned with.

635
00:31:47.140 --> 00:31:49.941
Most people don't understand half
the things that their tools can do.

636
00:31:49.941 --> 00:31:54.359
So if you get behind the wheel of
that Ferrari, you're gonna be a very,

637
00:31:54.359 --> 00:31:56.000
very well versed person.

638
00:31:56.000 --> 00:31:59.000
And something somebody's gonna
want to have in their club.

639
00:31:59.000 --> 00:32:01.050
That being said Adam,
we do appreciate you joining us.

640
00:32:01.050 --> 00:32:05.058
And showing us some of the tools that
might be available to us that we might

641
00:32:05.058 --> 00:32:08.520
need to use or be aware of for
our exam and real life as well.

642
00:32:08.520 --> 00:32:11.514
But it is that time for
us to go ahead and sign off.

643
00:32:11.514 --> 00:32:14.164
For ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

644
00:32:14.164 --> 00:32:15.162
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

645
00:32:15.162 --> 00:32:16.425
>> And we'll see you next time.

646
00:32:18.260 --> 00:32:24.412
[MUSIC]

647
00:32:24.412 --> 00:32:27.130
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam walk through the common types of malware that a CIH will have to deal with during any given incident. These malware types include Viruses, Worms, Spyware, and Trojans. Then they discuss how to identify whether a client is infected and then the steps taken to handle these incidents.
episodes.title: Malicious Code Incidents
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.082 --> 00:00:02.545
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.545 --> 00:00:08.520
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.520 --> 00:00:12.142
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.142 --> 00:00:13.553
>> All right, greetings everyone.

5
00:00:13.553 --> 00:00:16.550
And welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.550 --> 00:00:20.112
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

7
00:00:20.112 --> 00:00:22.970
we are coming back with
more on our ECIH series.

8
00:00:22.970 --> 00:00:26.027
And of course, joining us in the studio,
yet again, our sensei, our mentor.

9
00:00:26.027 --> 00:00:28.840
That is, the good man himself,
Mr Adam Gordon.

10
00:00:28.840 --> 00:00:31.470
Adam, welcome back,
my man, how's it going?

11
00:00:31.470 --> 00:00:32.500
[LAUGH].

12
00:00:32.500 --> 00:00:34.220
>> Very good.
My Kung Fu is strong today.

13
00:00:34.220 --> 00:00:34.890
>> It is.

14
00:00:34.890 --> 00:00:36.910
>> My Kung Fu is strong, and
hopefully yours will be as well.

15
00:00:36.910 --> 00:00:42.365
Because we are here to talk about
a topic that requires strong Kung Fu,

16
00:00:42.365 --> 00:00:44.090
strong karma.

17
00:00:44.090 --> 00:00:48.540
We need to talk about malware, viruses,
and things that go bump in the night,

18
00:00:48.540 --> 00:00:49.370
as they say.

19
00:00:49.370 --> 00:00:53.620
No good incident response, no good
incident handling, no good incident

20
00:00:53.620 --> 00:00:59.480
management story that we can tell, we can
discuss and/or relate doesn't somewhere

21
00:00:59.480 --> 00:01:03.875
have in it the idea that there was malware
on a machine or malware somewhere in

22
00:01:03.875 --> 00:01:07.800
a system that led to a compromise
that ultimately, we had to address.

23
00:01:07.800 --> 00:01:11.958
If you think about the way that more often
than not, we are called into action when

24
00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:15.827
we are doing incident response,
it's because something has gone wrong.

25
00:01:15.827 --> 00:01:19.220
I mean, let's be honest, when things
go right, we don't have a lot to do.

26
00:01:19.220 --> 00:01:20.567
We've talked about being prepared.

27
00:01:20.567 --> 00:01:24.402
We've talked about the importance
of making sure that we plan so

28
00:01:24.402 --> 00:01:29.850
that the bad things don't happen, and when
they do, that we minimize their impact.

29
00:01:29.850 --> 00:01:35.170
But we know that really the fun begins
when the bad stuff starts happening and

30
00:01:35.170 --> 00:01:39.940
we have to go respond and figure out
how to not only stop the bad stuff but

31
00:01:39.940 --> 00:01:41.640
then put things back to normal.

32
00:01:41.640 --> 00:01:44.510
And a lot of the time,
not all the time, but a very,

33
00:01:44.510 --> 00:01:48.470
very large percentage of the time,
the bad things we wind up stopping,

34
00:01:48.470 --> 00:01:52.980
the things we have to figure out how to
take apart and put back together again and

35
00:01:52.980 --> 00:01:57.100
ultimately return to normalcy through,
involve malware in one form or another.

36
00:01:57.100 --> 00:02:01.500
We used to talk years ago about malware
as being a separate category in and

37
00:02:01.500 --> 00:02:05.930
of itself and then we would talk about
things like Trojans and viruses and worms.

38
00:02:05.930 --> 00:02:09.850
Today when we say malware,
we generically mean pretty much any kind

39
00:02:09.850 --> 00:02:14.000
of software that has a negative
impact that is in some way going to

40
00:02:14.000 --> 00:02:19.000
deliver and/or propagate a payload
that leads to compromise.

41
00:02:19.000 --> 00:02:23.990
And so malware itself is a descriptive
category and a term that encompasses many

42
00:02:23.990 --> 00:02:28.260
of the things that we would, in some
cases, depending on how far back we go,

43
00:02:28.260 --> 00:02:32.850
perhaps break out and
talk about separately as well.

44
00:02:32.850 --> 00:02:39.030
Viruses, trojans, worms,
things of that nature, spyware, adware,

45
00:02:39.030 --> 00:02:44.230
all these kinds of things, all generically
today come up under the guise of malware.

46
00:02:44.230 --> 00:02:48.550
So as we begin to talk about malware,
we begin to talk about instant response,

47
00:02:48.550 --> 00:02:51.950
we're talking about software
that is of a dark nature.

48
00:02:51.950 --> 00:02:55.795
Software that comes from somewhere,
not controlled by us, most likely.

49
00:02:55.795 --> 00:02:58.920
Somewhere unknown to us, but
that's looking to do us harm.

50
00:02:58.920 --> 00:03:02.360
There are viruses, there are worms, let's
talk about the difference between them.

51
00:03:02.360 --> 00:03:04.320
Very subtle, but very important and

52
00:03:04.320 --> 00:03:07.740
distinct difference that we have to be
aware of, especially if you're planning on

53
00:03:07.740 --> 00:03:10.220
answering some questions at
some point in the future and

54
00:03:10.220 --> 00:03:13.040
perhaps putting some letters after
your name as a result of doing that.

55
00:03:13.040 --> 00:03:16.860
But whether you're doing that or not,
just as an in the field practitioner,

56
00:03:16.860 --> 00:03:21.880
somebody who as a security professional,
as an IT professional,

57
00:03:21.880 --> 00:03:26.300
as a network administrator, as anybody
doing anything in these fields today.

58
00:03:26.300 --> 00:03:29.110
You need to understand the different
between these terms cuz you have to

59
00:03:29.110 --> 00:03:30.880
understand how to address them.

60
00:03:30.880 --> 00:03:34.648
Viruses are gonna be executed or
brought into a system,

61
00:03:34.648 --> 00:03:38.500
typically through an attachment or
delivery through a program of some kind.

62
00:03:38.500 --> 00:03:40.930
But a user needs to interact
with them in some way.

63
00:03:40.930 --> 00:03:45.320
Helping them to spread and replicate
by executing or clicking on them or

64
00:03:45.320 --> 00:03:48.960
opening an attachment that's been
infected or whatever the case may be.

65
00:03:48.960 --> 00:03:51.380
But viruses do not self-replicate.

66
00:03:51.380 --> 00:03:54.480
Viruses require help in order to spread.

67
00:03:54.480 --> 00:03:56.260
Think about how you get
sick in the real world.

68
00:03:56.260 --> 00:04:01.180
If you catch the flu, catch some sort
of a bug, and you typically get it from

69
00:04:01.180 --> 00:04:04.530
somebody who's sick and gives it to
you through some sort of transmission

70
00:04:04.530 --> 00:04:08.580
mechanism, and then you go on and spread
the good word to other people, right?

71
00:04:08.580 --> 00:04:11.970
And that's how viruses are propagated
in the computer world as well.

72
00:04:11.970 --> 00:04:14.810
Worms, on the other hand,
are self-replicating.

73
00:04:14.810 --> 00:04:19.514
Once we kick them off, spawn them, and
somehow generate them, we step away.

74
00:04:19.514 --> 00:04:24.034
And unless there was some sort of
break in the transmission chain due to

75
00:04:24.034 --> 00:04:26.650
a cutting of the network capabilities.

76
00:04:26.650 --> 00:04:28.330
So we isolate the machine.

77
00:04:28.330 --> 00:04:31.540
No longer allow the virus, or
excuse me, the worm to propagate.

78
00:04:31.540 --> 00:04:32.970
That worm will continue to go out and

79
00:04:32.970 --> 00:04:37.770
infect systems on its own without having
to be spread by human interaction.

80
00:04:37.770 --> 00:04:39.442
One of the most successful
worms of all time,

81
00:04:39.442 --> 00:04:42.010
it's probably the most successful
piece of malware of all time,

82
00:04:42.010 --> 00:04:46.050
when we look at overall coverage based
on number of machines affected and

83
00:04:46.050 --> 00:04:49.942
those that were available at the time,
was the Robert Morris worm.

84
00:04:49.942 --> 00:04:54.235
This was the first example of malware of
a worm in the wild that was spread by

85
00:04:54.235 --> 00:04:58.265
accident if you go back and
understand the history of what happened.

86
00:04:58.265 --> 00:05:02.472
But ultimately, when you look at
the amount of machines that were effected

87
00:05:02.472 --> 00:05:04.875
on the networks connected at the time, and

88
00:05:04.875 --> 00:05:09.081
the coverage this worm was able to
achieve, it almost took advantage of and

89
00:05:09.081 --> 00:05:13.423
essentially connected to every machine
that was connected up to what we would

90
00:05:13.423 --> 00:05:17.492
think of now as the Internet, but
years ago was a very early form of that,

91
00:05:17.492 --> 00:05:21.710
much less pervasive than it is today,
much smaller than it is today.

92
00:05:21.710 --> 00:05:25.600
But achieved almost 100% coverage
across that network at the time.

93
00:05:25.600 --> 00:05:27.490
That is yet to be duplicated, thankfully.

94
00:05:27.490 --> 00:05:31.630
If you think about the potential liability
associated with a worm running wild today.

95
00:05:31.630 --> 00:05:36.570
Those of you that are old
enough that remember Slammer,

96
00:05:36.570 --> 00:05:42.531
remember Code Red, Nimda, some of these
worms that ran wild back in the last 15,

97
00:05:42.531 --> 00:05:46.790
20 years or so, or in the last 10 years,
or whatever the case may have been.

98
00:05:46.790 --> 00:05:49.580
But if you remember being in this
industry and working, if you

99
00:05:49.580 --> 00:05:53.868
are old enough to have actually been doing
this at the time these worms were around,

100
00:05:53.868 --> 00:05:57.800
and you lived through them firsthand
you know how destructive and

101
00:05:57.800 --> 00:05:59.980
how potentially problematic worms can be.

102
00:05:59.980 --> 00:06:03.370
Also, more importantly,
how incredibly difficult they are to stop.

103
00:06:03.370 --> 00:06:06.328
If you remember Slammer in particular and
Code Red.

104
00:06:06.328 --> 00:06:08.343
The minute you brought a machine up,

105
00:06:08.343 --> 00:06:12.760
connecting it to not only to your network,
but just to the outside world.

106
00:06:12.760 --> 00:06:15.400
Even through gateways,
firewalls, filters, etcetera.

107
00:06:15.400 --> 00:06:19.520
Within about 30 seconds, if that machine
had a vulnerability on it that would allow

108
00:06:19.520 --> 00:06:23.660
the worm to propagate, that machine
was probably attacked and infected and

109
00:06:23.660 --> 00:06:28.010
was then essentially re-exporting that
worm out to all machines on the inside

110
00:06:28.010 --> 00:06:30.080
of the firewall that could be affected.

111
00:06:30.080 --> 00:06:34.360
And this thing spread so quickly that
it was almost impossible to bring

112
00:06:34.360 --> 00:06:36.480
systems up without them being infected.

113
00:06:36.480 --> 00:06:40.370
So it can be very, very problematic when
worms run amok, thankfully we don't see

114
00:06:40.370 --> 00:06:44.150
them very often these days, but
when we do, you know, they are very, very

115
00:06:44.150 --> 00:06:47.635
difficult for us as incident responders
and incident handlers to address.

116
00:06:47.635 --> 00:06:50.440
Trojans, another category of
malware that we like to talk about.

117
00:06:51.520 --> 00:06:55.959
Programs masquerading inside of other
programs that are up to no good.

118
00:06:55.959 --> 00:07:00.160
So you think about a program that's
a nice shiny, happy program, right?

119
00:07:00.160 --> 00:07:04.296
Wallpaper, hey, let me download that
particular program, let me run that.

120
00:07:04.296 --> 00:07:06.868
And inside,
you get the wallpaper program, but

121
00:07:06.868 --> 00:07:09.815
you get something that's
a surprise as well, as Dan and

122
00:07:09.815 --> 00:07:13.980
I were chatting before we came on for
this particular episode, right?

123
00:07:13.980 --> 00:07:16.530
And so
if somebody sends you an attachment,

124
00:07:16.530 --> 00:07:20.110
you download a piece of software,
however you get there, that seemingly on

125
00:07:20.110 --> 00:07:24.035
the surface looks totally innocuous, how
do you really know what's inside of it?

126
00:07:24.035 --> 00:07:28.530
Unless you broke that software open,
examined it by taking it apart, and were

127
00:07:28.530 --> 00:07:32.000
able to understand what you were looking
at from a code perspective, you may have

128
00:07:32.000 --> 00:07:35.920
no way of knowing what that program
actually does or may have involved in it.

129
00:07:35.920 --> 00:07:39.710
And this is the danger of malware,
this is the danger of Trojans.

130
00:07:39.710 --> 00:07:44.468
We don't know what's wrapped up inside,
and it's the internal secondary program

131
00:07:44.468 --> 00:07:48.569
that is hidden from view that gets
executed that really does the damage.

132
00:07:48.569 --> 00:07:51.585
So you may be getting a lot more than
you bargained for, right, when you go to

133
00:07:51.585 --> 00:07:54.578
download something from a website that
you may or may not be familiar with.

134
00:07:54.578 --> 00:07:58.937
And, you know, no matter how much training
we do, No matter how much education we do,

135
00:07:58.937 --> 00:08:03.239
awareness we do, telling people hey, don't
go to these places things are too good to

136
00:08:03.239 --> 00:08:06.168
be true, somebody offers you
Microsoft Office for free,

137
00:08:06.168 --> 00:08:10.020
it's probably not Office and
it's definitely not gonna be free.

138
00:08:10.020 --> 00:08:12.340
You may not pay for it, but
you will pay for it later.

139
00:08:12.340 --> 00:08:14.880
You just may not pay for
it upfront with money, right?

140
00:08:14.880 --> 00:08:19.060
These are things that people
unfortunately don't really listen to.

141
00:08:19.060 --> 00:08:21.510
These are lessons that you
have to learn the hard way.

142
00:08:21.510 --> 00:08:25.760
I remember being a kid and I remember in
my grandmother's house, there was a lamp,

143
00:08:25.760 --> 00:08:26.380
one of those, hey,

144
00:08:26.380 --> 00:08:30.210
don't touch it deals, like special
super duper lamp, don't touch it.

145
00:08:30.210 --> 00:08:32.240
I remember touching it and
nothing happens.

146
00:08:32.240 --> 00:08:33.810
So I'm like all right, well, whatever.

147
00:08:33.810 --> 00:08:35.470
So I'll just play with whatever I want.

148
00:08:35.470 --> 00:08:37.440
Well, it wasn't don't touch
it cuz you would break it,

149
00:08:37.440 --> 00:08:39.730
it was don't touch it because
it wasn't wired properly.

150
00:08:39.730 --> 00:08:41.100
It wasn't grounded and

151
00:08:41.100 --> 00:08:44.690
if you touched it when it was on,
you would light up like a Christmas tree.

152
00:08:44.690 --> 00:08:48.290
And so I remember, you know,
thinking I knew better.

153
00:08:48.290 --> 00:08:52.390
And of course I went to touch it when
it happened to have been plugged in and

154
00:08:52.390 --> 00:08:55.325
my eyes spun around my sockets, right?

155
00:08:55.325 --> 00:08:55.890
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because, you know,

156
00:08:55.890 --> 00:08:56.814
I got zapped [CROSSTALK]
everything wasn't grounded.

157
00:08:56.814 --> 00:08:57.758
>> A wake up call that day?

158
00:08:57.758 --> 00:09:01.495
>> Yeah, that was quite a wake up call I
remember to this day what that felt like,

159
00:09:01.495 --> 00:09:04.830
and so the reality is there are some
lessons that you just have to learn

160
00:09:04.830 --> 00:09:08.624
the hard way, no matter how much we tell
you to the contrary, there are certain

161
00:09:08.624 --> 00:09:12.930
things you're just gonna have to be
stupid about and figure out for yourself.

162
00:09:12.930 --> 00:09:15.670
Don't let this be one of them,
is what I'm suggesting to you, right?

163
00:09:15.670 --> 00:09:16.720
And I know it's not you.

164
00:09:17.800 --> 00:09:20.550
I know it's not the people that
are listening to me and are listening to

165
00:09:20.550 --> 00:09:23.780
us right now that we have to worry about,
because I know you get it, right.

166
00:09:23.780 --> 00:09:26.800
The whole reason you're here,
whole reason you do what you do,

167
00:09:26.800 --> 00:09:29.200
is because you understand
the importance of this.

168
00:09:29.200 --> 00:09:32.850
It's the people that you have to reach,
in your networks, in your organization.

169
00:09:32.850 --> 00:09:33.400
The people, two,

170
00:09:33.400 --> 00:09:37.930
three levels down stream from us,
that are the people that may not get it.

171
00:09:37.930 --> 00:09:41.050
And the people that we have to figure
how to create awareness around and

172
00:09:41.050 --> 00:09:44.470
in their minds create a sense
of urgency around the fact that

173
00:09:44.470 --> 00:09:46.700
these things can be problematic, right?

174
00:09:46.700 --> 00:09:49.980
They can hurt us and
it may not be easy to come back from that.

175
00:09:49.980 --> 00:09:52.940
And they can cause catastrophic damage and
loss and so

176
00:09:52.940 --> 00:09:55.210
we have to find ways to raise awareness.

177
00:09:55.210 --> 00:09:59.390
Making examples available to people,
showing them the impact of this,

178
00:09:59.390 --> 00:10:01.760

00:24:11.960 --> 00:24:12.870

00:24:19.930 --> 00:24:21.350

00:24:21.350 --> 00:24:24.431

how do you think we bring this kind of

00:24:24.431 --> 00:24:26.980
stuff into your organizations

495
00:24:26.980 --> 00:24:28.740
Because nobody takes a look at that and

496
00:24:28.740 --> 00:24:32.260

497
00:24:32.260 --> 00:24:34.773
The only people smart enough to

498
00:24:34.773 --> 00:24:36.158

499
00:24:36.158 --> 00:24:39.326
Where they won't allow you to bring
this stuff in, cuz they know better.

500
00:24:39.326 --> 00:24:42.800
But in average corporate environments

501
00:24:42.800 --> 00:24:44.145
You could walk in with a bazooka.

502
00:24:44.145 --> 00:24:46.160
Nobody would give you a second look,

503
00:24:46.160 --> 00:24:49.974
So the reality is that there's so
many ways that this stuff infiltrates

504
00:24:49.974 --> 00:24:53.920
into networks today,
we've got to be on guard all the time.

505
00:24:53.920 --> 00:24:57.250
One of the biggest things you can do as
incident responders to prevent this kinda

506
00:24:57.250 --> 00:25:01.230
stuff, create an ant-tethering,
anti-use policy around these devices.

507
00:25:01.230 --> 00:25:05.372
I love when I go on site and

508
00:25:05.372 --> 00:25:09.690
in the general cube farm and

509
00:25:09.690 --> 00:25:12.319
It's almost like watching The Matrix

510
00:25:12.319 --> 00:25:13.970

00:25:13.970 --> 00:25:18.480
I see all of this opportunity as
a bad actor because I see everybody

513
00:25:22.550 --> 00:25:23.487
Even a cellphone or

514

and/or external memory storage.

515
00:25:27.070 --> 00:25:28.820
You know what kinda stuff
you could put in there?

516
00:25:28.820 --> 00:25:30.240
We've already talked about this right?

517
00:25:30.240 --> 00:25:35.370
You tether that device to a corporate
owned asset and you hook it up wirelessly.

518
00:25:35.370 --> 00:25:38.530
Now we've successfully bridged
the outside and the inside right?

519
00:25:38.530 --> 00:25:40.570
Together.
And you've opened up a pathway for

520
00:25:40.570 --> 00:25:41.800
a hacker.

521
00:25:41.800 --> 00:25:45.536
Perhaps, depending on how you set that up,
to potentially get right into the machine.

522
00:25:45.536 --> 00:25:48.790
Now, many corporations,

523
00:25:48.790 --> 00:25:50.212

524
00:25:50.212 --> 00:25:52.550
They don't allow those

00:25:52.550 --> 00:25:54.410
They may allow them to power up to charge.

526
00:25:54.410 --> 00:25:56.695
They won't allow them to be

527
00:25:56.695 --> 00:25:58.370
But, what about the ones that don't?

528
00:25:58.370 --> 00:25:59.940
All it takes is one, by the way, right?

529
00:26:01.100 --> 00:26:02.540
Got to think about this kind of stuff.

530
00:26:02.540 --> 00:26:04.310
This is where incident handling,

531

incident response with regards to malware
becomes a big deal for us, right?

532
00:26:08.330 --> 00:26:12.210
We have to think about the fact that
to identify infected hosts, you know,

533
00:26:12.210 --> 00:26:15.770
we can do this front line and center,

00:26:15.770 --> 00:26:16.600

535
00:26:16.600 --> 00:26:17.780
We've been talking about that.

536
00:26:17.780 --> 00:26:20.100
We can use active identification
through scanning.

537
00:26:20.100 --> 00:26:21.450
We've talked about that as well.

538
00:26:21.450 --> 00:26:23.721
We could forensically examine
a host after the fact.

539
00:26:23.721 --> 00:26:24.973
And unwind what's happened.

540
00:26:24.973 --> 00:26:27.820
We talked about this and
the issues and concerns here.

541
00:26:27.820 --> 00:26:29.690
There's lots of ways to do this.

542
00:26:29.690 --> 00:26:33.180
But we have to understand
that the best of all worlds

543
00:26:33.180 --> 00:26:36.970
is to prevent it before it is allowed
to touch the system in the first place.

544
00:26:36.970 --> 00:26:40.780
If I have to remediate the system after
the fact, if I have to forensically

545
00:26:40.780 --> 00:26:44.417
examine the system and undo the damage,
I've already lost, right?

546
00:26:44.417 --> 00:26:46.940
All I'm doing is cleaning up
somebody else's mess at that point.

547
00:26:46.940 --> 00:26:49.750
I'm hoping I do a good job,
and let's hope I do.

548
00:26:49.750 --> 00:26:54.790
But the reality is I'm unfortunately
reacting as opposed to being proactive.

549
00:26:54.790 --> 00:26:58.430
And we're never coming from a position
of strength when we're reacting.

550
00:26:58.430 --> 00:27:00.560
We're always playing by
somebody else's rules.

551
00:27:00.560 --> 00:27:03.660
And this is what we have to realize and
think about with regards to malware.

552
00:27:05.280 --> 00:27:09.240
>> Malware, bad stuff,
don't get it cuz it's bad.

553
00:27:09.240 --> 00:27:10.290
You don't want it.

554
00:27:10.290 --> 00:27:12.540
We've gone through a few

555
00:27:12.540 --> 00:27:15.810
Now hopefully you have a good

556

557

558

559

560
00:27:27.240 --> 00:27:31.910
What's the methodology we need to

561
00:27:31.910 --> 00:27:37.240

562

I've been down that road, though.

00:27:38.380 --> 00:27:43.210
And it is something that's probably going

565

47

I had to say that seriously so I didn't

57

don'ts are that can lead

58

know about, have a working knowledge of.

661
00:31:21.950 --> 00:31:25.170
And how to counteract someone
that might be using something

662
00:31:25.170 --> 00:31:26.610
as a threat against our networks.

663
00:31:26.610 --> 00:31:29.940
That being said, I'm looking at the clock,
we have run out of time for this episode.

664
00:31:29.940 --> 00:31:33.380
Thanks so much for joining us, Adam, and
thank you guys so much for watching.

665
00:31:33.380 --> 00:31:38.080
But it's time to sign off, for ITPRO.TV
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie,

666
00:31:38.080 --> 00:31:40.990
I'm a stealthy keylogger coming
soon to a machine near you.

667
00:31:40.990 --> 00:31:42.760
>> And we'll see you next time.

668
00:31:42.760 --> 00:31:45.324
>> Take care everybody
>> Bye.

669

>> [MUSIC]

670

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore forensic analysis from the perspective of a CIH. They start by defining what computer forensics is and present a methodology for implementation. Then they explain the types of computer forensics, the computer forensics process, and even look at forensics tools like Helix for performing an investigation.

23

Specifically, thought we'd spend some
time talking about forensics and

24

incident handling.

25
00:00:44.810 --> 00:00:48.480
And how the two, forensic analysis and
incident handling, kinda go hand in hand.

26
00:00:48.480 --> 00:00:51.170
We've talked in some other
episodes prior to this

27
00:00:51.170 --> 00:00:53.950
about the concepts of forensic analysis.

28
00:00:53.950 --> 00:00:57.850
How we manage incident response from
a forensically sound standpoint.

29
00:00:57.850 --> 00:01:00.560
What do we need to do to safeguard data?

30
00:01:00.560 --> 00:01:02.940
How do we address those
concerns when we show up and

31

deal with a potential crime scene or
an incident scene?

32
00:01:06.080 --> 00:01:09.610

all the stuff that may go on there?

33

Gotta think about all that.

34

I thought we dig a little bit deeper into
some of that today or at least right now.

35
00:01:14.670 --> 00:01:16.350
Talk a bit about that.

36
00:01:16.350 --> 00:01:20.560
When we think about computer forensics or
generally just forensics overall,

37
00:01:20.560 --> 00:01:24.800
we're thinking about a science that is
really focused on or a discipline that is

38
00:01:24.800 --> 00:01:30.210
focused on looking at the ability to be
able to gather evidence in a sound manner,

39
00:01:30.210 --> 00:01:35.070
and then safeguard that evidence through
a series of meticulously planned, thought

40
00:01:35.070 --> 00:01:40.410
out, and executed steps that establish
what we refer to us chain of custody.

41
00:01:40.410 --> 00:01:42.550
We understand the concept as being,

42
00:01:42.550 --> 00:01:46.150
do we have knowledge of
the state of that evidence.

43
00:01:46.150 --> 00:01:49.970
Evidence being whatever we've gathered
from the particular target environment

44
00:01:49.970 --> 00:01:51.060
that we're examining.

45
00:01:51.060 --> 00:01:55.180
Do we understand the state of that
evidence at every moment in time?

46
00:01:55.180 --> 00:02:00.770
From the time we come upon it and we first
examine it, document its current state,

47
00:02:00.770 --> 00:02:05.550
capture it in some way that allows us to
safeguard that state and understand it.

48
00:02:05.550 --> 00:02:07.080
And then, store it and work with it,

49
00:02:07.080 --> 00:02:09.640
potentially, through
the end of that life cycle.

50
00:02:09.640 --> 00:02:12.060
Whether it is showing up at trial.

51
00:02:12.060 --> 00:02:15.700
Whether it is to create an analysis and
then report on it,

52
00:02:15.700 --> 00:02:20.180
and perhaps, at that point, give it back
if we find there's no longer any value.

53
00:02:20.180 --> 00:02:24.030
Or to destroy it, depending on what
happens at the end of that ultimate chain.

54
00:02:24.030 --> 00:02:29.500
But throughout that entire time from
discovery through acquisition through

55
00:02:29.500 --> 00:02:33.900
analysis, through storage, however long
that takes out through the end of that,

56
00:02:33.900 --> 00:02:38.490
to establish a forensically sound
handling pattern and set of

57
00:02:38.490 --> 00:02:42.540
activities in an environment that allow us
to account for the state of that evidence.

58
00:02:42.540 --> 00:02:45.750
Every moment in time, unequivocally,
without any failures or

59
00:02:45.750 --> 00:02:49.220
gaps is what we talk about with regards
to the chain of custody of evidence.

60
00:02:49.220 --> 00:02:53.640
And so, thinking about that combing
elements of law and computer science to

61
00:02:53.640 --> 00:02:58.870
collect and analyze data from one or more
systems, networks, wireless communication,

62
00:02:58.870 --> 00:03:03.570
environments, whatever the case maybe,
storage devices, things of that nature.

63
00:03:03.570 --> 00:03:06.360
In a way that's admissible as
evidence in a court of law

64
00:03:06.360 --> 00:03:08.350
is really what computer
forensics focuses on.

65
00:03:08.350 --> 00:03:11.150
It's what we think about,
it's what we define it as.

66
00:03:11.150 --> 00:03:14.610
There's a methodology associated with
forensics as I was saying and suggesting,

67
00:03:14.610 --> 00:03:18.770
and at a high level, that methodology
is made up of five key steps.

68
00:03:18.770 --> 00:03:20.030
Wanna know what they are?

69
00:03:20.030 --> 00:03:25.740
Obviously, important for you as a security
professional, as an IT administrator,

70
00:03:25.740 --> 00:03:29.330
as a potential incident handler,
to have understanding of this.

71
00:03:29.330 --> 00:03:32.870
It's important for you in the real world
to understand what the methodology is so

72
00:03:32.870 --> 00:03:34.340
you can execute it properly.

73
00:03:34.340 --> 00:03:38.080
Support and understand also that if you're
asked questions about this hypothetically

74
00:03:38.080 --> 00:03:41.340
at some point, you would want to be
able to answer them authoritatively.

75
00:03:41.340 --> 00:03:44.810
It's also important to understand
that you need to be trained

76
00:03:44.810 --> 00:03:46.310
to do this properly, right?

77
00:03:46.310 --> 00:03:48.930
This is something I can't
stress enough to you.

78
00:03:48.930 --> 00:03:52.020
This is not the kind of thing,
this being forensic analysis.

79
00:03:52.020 --> 00:03:55.830
This is not the kind of thing that
you just read a book on and go, yeah,

80
00:03:55.830 --> 00:03:57.410
I could do that, right, no problem.

81
00:03:57.410 --> 00:03:59.390
I watched the YouTube video, no big deal.

82
00:03:59.390 --> 00:04:02.560
I can go ahead, I could do that and
I will be fine, right?

83
00:04:02.560 --> 00:04:04.150
I mean, you could in theory.

84
00:04:04.150 --> 00:04:06.700
I'm not suggesting that you
couldn't acquire the skills.

85
00:04:06.700 --> 00:04:11.120
What I'm suggesting is that having the
skills is different from understanding how

86
00:04:11.120 --> 00:04:14.380
to execute those skills in
a forensically sound way.

87
00:04:14.380 --> 00:04:18.190
We could teach you easily how to
acquire data from a hard drive.

88
00:04:18.190 --> 00:04:21.080
And to do so in a way that would
allow you to capture that data, but

89
00:04:21.080 --> 00:04:23.900
doing so using the proper forensics tools.

90
00:04:23.900 --> 00:04:25.510
A right blocker, for instance.

91
00:04:25.510 --> 00:04:30.110
A device that allows data to be pulled
out of a system going one way, but

92
00:04:30.110 --> 00:04:34.620
doesn't allow bidirectional communication
coming back in to the target drive, or,

93
00:04:34.620 --> 00:04:36.110
excuse me, to the source drive.

94
00:04:36.110 --> 00:04:40.990
So, that way, we're not able to disrupt or
in any way add or modify the data that

95
00:04:40.990 --> 00:04:44.940
is there guaranteeing the integrity
of that data in the current state and

96
00:04:44.940 --> 00:04:46.520
at the moment we capture it.

97
00:04:46.520 --> 00:04:48.520
That is something you need
to be trained to do and

98
00:04:48.520 --> 00:04:51.230
be trained to understand
how to do properly.

99
00:04:51.230 --> 00:04:55.200
The lack of a use of right blockers
indicates that that drive data, or

100
00:04:55.200 --> 00:04:57.640
whatever data you capture,
is not forensically sound,

101
00:04:57.640 --> 00:04:59.140
cannot be used as evidence.

102
00:04:59.140 --> 00:05:04.320
And Without using a write blocker, you
will destroy any possibility of gathering

103
00:05:04.320 --> 00:05:07.540
any evidence from that system because the
evidence will be seen as being tainted.

104
00:05:07.540 --> 00:05:11.920
No matter what you do at that point,
you've probably modified timestamps,

105
00:05:11.920 --> 00:05:15.140
system status, system data, etcetera.

106
00:05:15.140 --> 00:05:18.400
And now, you've essentially wiped out
any opportunity for us to be able

107
00:05:18.400 --> 00:05:22.650
to use the data that we may find there to
be able to establish cause and effect and

108
00:05:22.650 --> 00:05:25.100
to do so
in a way that is beyond reproach, and

109
00:05:25.100 --> 00:05:28.635
leads to the opportunity to present
that data to make definitive and

110
00:05:28.635 --> 00:05:30.605
declarative statements about what may or
may not have happened.

111
00:05:30.605 --> 00:05:35.785
And draw conclusions that can be presented
in a court of law, in a court of inquiry,

112
00:05:35.785 --> 00:05:39.005
before a panel of people that may
wanna understand more about it,

113
00:05:39.005 --> 00:05:40.707
whatever the case may be.

114
00:05:40.707 --> 00:05:44.917
And so, we have to understand that
the methodology involved is very,

115
00:05:44.917 --> 00:05:49.337
very important for practitioners but
training to become and

116
00:05:49.337 --> 00:05:53.067
to understand how to become a forensics
expert, to understand how to do this

117
00:05:53.067 --> 00:05:56.057
properly, is critical for
your ability to do this successfully.

118
00:05:56.057 --> 00:05:58.827
So, the methodology, five steps,
important to know them.

119
00:05:58.827 --> 00:05:59.457
Know them in order.

120
00:06:00.510 --> 00:06:06.290
Preservation, identification, extraction,
interpretation, and documentation.

121
00:06:06.290 --> 00:06:09.940
So, making sure we understand
the preservation of the crime scene,

122
00:06:09.940 --> 00:06:12.710
of the evidence of whatever it may be,
the incident involved.

123
00:06:12.710 --> 00:06:17.228
Identification of all the items that
have to be ultimately gathered from,

124
00:06:17.228 --> 00:06:19.100
analyzed, and documented.

125
00:06:19.100 --> 00:06:22.700
Extraction, the ability to pull data,
pull evidence out of one or

126
00:06:22.700 --> 00:06:25.820
more of those systems, but
again in a forensically sound way.

127
00:06:25.820 --> 00:06:29.850
Interpretation is essentially
analysis of the extracted data.

128
00:06:29.850 --> 00:06:32.260
And then documentation is reporting,
right?

129
00:06:32.260 --> 00:06:35.566
Being able to write up what we found,
do so in an audience-friendly,

130
00:06:35.566 --> 00:06:39.770
audience-relevant and appropriate manner,
and communicate broadly and widely.

131
00:06:39.770 --> 00:06:42.930
To whoever may need to see that in
a way that makes sense for them, and

132
00:06:44.130 --> 00:06:48.610
reproduce information about the incident,
that we can then draw conclusions from.

133
00:06:48.610 --> 00:06:51.600
Having done all that,
we've met the five criteria.

134
00:06:51.600 --> 00:06:55.880
The five key checkpoints or milestones
that we have to execute on in order to say

135
00:06:55.880 --> 00:06:59.630
that we've done things and executed things
in a way that is forensically sound.

136
00:06:59.630 --> 00:07:02.630
So, we do want to make sure we're
aware of that and understand that.

137
00:07:02.630 --> 00:07:06.080
Also the main objectives regards
to computer for instance, right?

138
00:07:06.080 --> 00:07:09.320
So, if I ask you Daniel cuz you've been so

139
00:07:09.320 --> 00:07:10.040
silent there,
>> [LAUGH]

140
00:07:10.040 --> 00:07:11.540
>> For the last few minutes.

141
00:07:11.540 --> 00:07:14.702
But if I ask you, what do you think
some of the main objectives, right,

142
00:07:14.702 --> 00:07:15.883
of our computer friends?

143
00:07:15.883 --> 00:07:17.284
What would be on the top of your head?

144
00:07:17.284 --> 00:07:18.422
What would be in your list?

145
00:07:18.422 --> 00:07:20.262
>> First thing I would think of
is the gathering of the evidence.

146
00:07:20.262 --> 00:07:23.734
To figure out, what is evidence
that's going to lead us to?

147
00:07:23.734 --> 00:07:25.686
How this happened?

148
00:07:25.686 --> 00:07:28.770
Why this happened and who did this?

149
00:07:28.770 --> 00:07:30.910
That's what would be the top of my list.

150
00:07:30.910 --> 00:07:33.070
>> All right, so
essentially identification of evidence.

151
00:07:33.070 --> 00:07:35.340
And perhaps through
the identification of evidence,

152
00:07:35.340 --> 00:07:39.150
start to begin to be able to sketch
a story or sketch out a picture, right?

153
00:07:39.150 --> 00:07:43.000
Creating picture in our minds begin to
tell the story of what that incident may

154
00:07:43.000 --> 00:07:47.050
have been, what the motivations were, what
the reasons were, things of that nature.

155
00:07:47.050 --> 00:07:50.597
So, being able to recover, being able to
analyze, being able to interpret that

156
00:07:50.597 --> 00:07:54.156
data, but to do so in a forensically sound
way would be one of the key objectives.

157
00:07:54.156 --> 00:07:57.048
Also, how to do so
in a time sensitive way, right?

158
00:07:57.048 --> 00:07:58.120
This is also important.

159
00:07:58.120 --> 00:08:01.968
We don't wanna take Hours,
days, months, years, right,

160
00:08:01.968 --> 00:08:05.306
[LAUGH] to examine this incident and
this crime scene.

161
00:08:05.306 --> 00:08:07.874
There may be an issue
associated with time and

162
00:08:07.874 --> 00:08:11.331
the loss of the ability to
understand certain kinds of data.

163
00:08:11.331 --> 00:08:13.210
Because it is perishable,
because it is dynamic.

164
00:08:13.210 --> 00:08:14.688
It is what we call volatile.

165
00:08:14.688 --> 00:08:18.496
And if we don't have the right
response at the right time based on

166
00:08:18.496 --> 00:08:20.670
the volatility of the evidence.

167
00:08:20.670 --> 00:08:22.177
We may lose the opportunity
to capture that evidence.

168
00:08:22.177 --> 00:08:25.830
So, being time-sensitive
because of evidence volatility.

169
00:08:25.830 --> 00:08:30.210
Is also one of the key thought processes
and main objectives of computer forensics.

170
00:08:30.210 --> 00:08:33.392
Capturing evidence in a time-sensitive way

171
00:08:33.392 --> 00:08:37.470
based on what we call order
of volatility of evidence.

172
00:08:37.470 --> 00:08:39.392
Some evidence is more perishable and

173
00:08:39.392 --> 00:08:41.878
therefore needs to be
captured before others.

174
00:08:41.878 --> 00:08:44.178
Memory register data, cache data,

175
00:08:44.178 --> 00:08:48.560
things like that that's in the dynamic
memory or RAM of a system.

176
00:08:48.560 --> 00:08:50.420
Is much more important to capture.

177
00:08:50.420 --> 00:08:54.207
Because once we turn the machine
off that data is gone forever.

178
00:08:54.207 --> 00:08:59.676
Versus the state of the machine,
the cabling around the machine,

179
00:08:59.676 --> 00:09:03.110
the peripherals that are plugged in.

180
00:09:03.110 --> 00:09:04.260
You can turn the machine off and

181
00:09:04.260 --> 00:09:06.160
essentially none of that would change,
right?

182
00:09:06.160 --> 00:09:08.810
The wiring itself would
still be in the same place.

183
00:09:08.810 --> 00:09:11.690
And the fact that I have
a mouse attached to the machine

184
00:09:11.690 --> 00:09:15.280
via the right-hand side
USB port would not change.

185
00:09:15.280 --> 00:09:18.361
And as a result, if I powered off
the machine, I would still be able to take

186
00:09:18.361 --> 00:09:20.767
a picture of all that, and
that would be perfectly fine.

187
00:09:20.767 --> 00:09:24.970
But what's in memory would evaporate
the second the power is gone.

188
00:09:24.970 --> 00:09:28.705
And so there's definitely an important
need for a forensic analyst.

189
00:09:28.705 --> 00:09:33.664
For an incident handler that is doing
the job of the forensic investigator to

190
00:09:33.664 --> 00:09:35.921
understand order of volatility.

191
00:09:35.921 --> 00:09:40.291
Because if we don't capture cached data,
cache, as in C-A-C-H-E, or

192
00:09:40.291 --> 00:09:43.490
cash-ay, as some people like to say,
right?

193
00:09:43.490 --> 00:09:48.030
Cache data, register data that's
in memory, those kind of things.

194
00:09:48.030 --> 00:09:48.730
We're done, right?

195
00:09:48.730 --> 00:09:51.940
And so, for instance, one thing, if we can
just take a look at my machine here for

196
00:09:51.940 --> 00:09:53.430
just one second.

197
00:09:53.430 --> 00:09:55.443
We're gonna pretend you're not
looking at Helix right now.

198
00:09:55.443 --> 00:09:57.478
Cuz that's gonna be
an upcoming demonstration for

199
00:09:57.478 --> 00:09:59.520
you in regards to how we
do some forensic analysis.

200
00:09:59.520 --> 00:10:01.450
But I just wanted to
show you one quick thing.

201
00:10:01.450 --> 00:10:05.330
With regards to the order of volatility
and why it's so important to do this.

202
00:10:05.330 --> 00:10:09.496
And I've done this
demonstration in other systems,

203
00:10:09.496 --> 00:10:12.467
in other episodes for other reasons.

204
00:10:12.467 --> 00:10:15.342
But I'm gonna do it here with you
now again just to make sure we're

205
00:10:15.342 --> 00:10:16.350
comfortable with it.

206
00:10:16.350 --> 00:10:19.940
Let me just change the background
on this real quick, and

207
00:10:19.940 --> 00:10:23.380
you can see this particular
demo is a realtime demo.

208
00:10:23.380 --> 00:10:26.181
I didn't plan for it ahead of time,
so I don't have my font size and

209
00:10:26.181 --> 00:10:27.041
everything set up.

210
00:10:27.041 --> 00:10:29.800
So we're just gonna quickly
modify the background here so

211
00:10:29.800 --> 00:10:32.010
you guys can see this a little bit better.

212
00:10:32.010 --> 00:10:35.880
Cuz normally when we do this in the
command line, we already have it set up,

213
00:10:35.880 --> 00:10:36.730
comes up like that.

214
00:10:36.730 --> 00:10:38.410
It's a lot easier for you guys to see.

215
00:10:38.410 --> 00:10:40.488
Now you know all my secrets and
you know I get that, right?

episodes.description: Watch Adam and Cherokee define and discuss digital evidence. Adam gives us 5 Be's to help us remember important characteristics of digital evidence. Collecting digital evidence in the order of volatility is a must because precious evidence may be lost if power is lost. Also, it is important not to rewrite any information present. Adam gives us some tools to help create copies which can be used for analysis.

1

13

We have been talking about forensic
analysis as she was just saying and during

14

15

incident handlers, incident managers,

21

Network forensics, computer forensics,

25

26

Of places where information may scurry

27

28

29

31

The concept of Kerckhoffs' principle,
which we didn't really talk about and

On forensics, entire set of episodes
there that really goes in depth into

what we're talking about here.

37
00:01:59.120 --> 00:02:04.000
But in Kerckhoffs's principle, the idea
is that whenever you have a transaction

38
00:02:04.000 --> 00:02:08.613
between, let's say somebody who commits
a crime, an incident in our case.

39
00:02:08.613 --> 00:02:11.179
And the machine or the entity or

40

42
00:02:17.280 --> 00:02:20.044
That's what Kerckhoffs's principle
represents in the study of criminalistics

43
00:02:20.044 --> 00:02:20.611
and forensics.

44
00:02:20.611 --> 00:02:24.521
And the idea behind this being that,
if the bad actor,

45
00:02:24.521 --> 00:02:28.180
the threat source has some sort of agenda,

46
00:02:28.180 --> 00:02:32.060
And they're gonna come in and potentially,

It's blue, it's pretty,

49
00:02:35.231 --> 00:02:37.260
It's very nice mouse, right?

50
00:02:37.260 --> 00:02:40.382
I don't want anybody to take it, but
if they come in and try to steal my mouse.

51
00:02:40.382 --> 00:02:43.917
Then if I show up on Monday morning and
see the mouse as gone,

52
00:02:43.917 --> 00:02:46.440
I know something has been removed.

53
00:02:46.440 --> 00:02:50.407
But in addition to that, I can tell
most likely, more often than not,

54
00:02:50.407 --> 00:02:53.569
despite what you see on crime

55
00:02:53.569 --> 00:02:56.750
in TV, more often people
leave things behind, right?

56
00:02:56.750 --> 00:03:01.040
There may be a fingerprint, maybe
there's DNA, who knows what there is.

57
00:03:01.040 --> 00:03:05.102
Maybe they were sloppy and left something
on the table, whatever it may be, right?

58
00:03:05.102 --> 00:03:07.160
>> So Adam,
it's interesting you say fingerprint.

59

are we really talking

63
00:03:18.387 --> 00:03:20.057
>> So it's a great though process.

64
00:03:20.057 --> 00:03:22.464
We could talk about a lot
of different things.

65
00:03:22.464 --> 00:03:23.922
A fingerprint generically, right?

66
00:03:23.922 --> 00:03:26.560
Could be almost anything,
as Cherokee is pointing out.

67
00:03:26.560 --> 00:03:28.570
It could be a log,
an entry in a log, right?

68
00:03:28.570 --> 00:03:30.853
It could be perhaps the absence

69

>> Okay.
>> The antithesis of what she was just

saying, which is hey,

a log that says I tried to log in and

72
00:03:39.770 --> 00:03:42.650
Well they may have, but
the threat source, the bad actor,

73
00:03:42.650 --> 00:03:46.930
may have been smart enough to realize
that that may be a tell tale sign.

74
00:03:46.930 --> 00:03:49.093
Maybe if they modify the log and
remove that entry,

75
00:03:49.093 --> 00:03:52.228
then hopefully they're covering
their tracks from their perspective.

76
00:03:52.228 --> 00:03:57.119
But if we're smart enough, maybe we're
looking at that log, noticing a gap or

77
00:03:57.119 --> 00:03:59.530
noticing some sort of oddity, right?

78
00:03:59.530 --> 00:04:01.440
Maybe those entries don't line up,

79
00:04:01.440 --> 00:04:05.940
maybe they'll look proper, maybe there's

80
00:04:05.940 --> 00:04:09.190
And if we spend a little bit of time
looking at them, maybe we'll uncover that.

81
00:04:09.190 --> 00:04:11.040
And so
this idea of what gets left behind and

82
00:04:11.040 --> 00:04:16.170
what is taken with is one of the things
we look at from a forensics perspective.

83
00:04:16.170 --> 00:04:18.710
We've talked a lot about
the fact that digital evidence

84
00:04:18.710 --> 00:04:21.380
is really defined as
something that adds value.

85
00:04:21.380 --> 00:04:23.168
It has to be probative in value.

86
00:04:23.168 --> 00:04:29.000
It has to add value, add explanatory
value to the incident in a positive way.

87
00:04:29.000 --> 00:04:34.370
A way that allows us to understand and to
through analysis ultimately tells a story.

88
00:04:34.370 --> 00:04:38.330
But it has to do so in a way that does
not jaundice or in any way bias or

89
00:04:38.330 --> 00:04:39.550
modify the facts.

90
00:04:39.550 --> 00:04:42.795
In other words,
if we can't establish chain of custody,

91
00:04:42.795 --> 00:04:48.080
can't establish and understand definitely
that the evidence has not been modified,

92
00:04:48.080 --> 00:04:49.205
integrity is intact.

93
00:04:49.205 --> 00:04:53.189
We've ensure that through proper handling
procedures, through digital signatures,

94
00:04:53.189 --> 00:04:55.852
hashing, all things we've talked about or
been through.

95
00:04:55.852 --> 00:04:59.851
If those things are not present,
the evidence is most likely not useful and

96
00:04:59.851 --> 00:05:02.582
will as we've talked about,
more often than not,

97
00:05:02.582 --> 00:05:05.410
not be allowed to be
presented in a court of law.

98
00:05:05.410 --> 00:05:07.862
You may still use that inside
the organization, right?

99
00:05:07.862 --> 00:05:10.954
In other words, you may be able
to create an incident report,

100
00:05:10.954 --> 00:05:14.759
tell the story of the incident,
even though you may not have forensically,

101
00:05:14.759 --> 00:05:17.360
soundly analyzed and
gathered the evidence.

102
00:05:17.360 --> 00:05:21.409
It may not in other words, meet the bar or
the expectation for value and for

103
00:05:21.409 --> 00:05:23.444
presentation before a court of law.

104
00:05:23.444 --> 00:05:27.131
That doesn't come to use internally,
but it does mean that when

105
00:05:27.131 --> 00:05:31.060
you go outside the organization to
go to bringing law enforcement.

106
00:05:31.060 --> 00:05:34.916
We've talked about this, how do you
approach external law enforcement?

107
00:05:34.916 --> 00:05:37.508
What level or
what art of responses they come in,

108
00:05:37.508 --> 00:05:40.494
when they come in does that
change the rules of the game?

109
00:05:40.494 --> 00:05:44.793
The answer is absolutely, and when you
do those kind of things at that point,

110
00:05:44.793 --> 00:05:48.499
evidence that has not been handled
correctly is more often than not

111
00:05:48.499 --> 00:05:49.240
thrown out.

112
00:05:49.240 --> 00:05:51.514
Unfortunately, it's just
not seen as being valuable.

113
00:05:51.514 --> 00:05:54.414
It doesn't exist, in the eyes of
the law and the eyes of the court.

114
00:05:54.414 --> 00:05:55.947
And this is a big deal, right?

115
00:05:55.947 --> 00:05:58.367
Because if we screw it up,
let's be honest,

116
00:05:58.367 --> 00:06:00.825
that's what we're talking about, right?

117
00:06:00.825 --> 00:06:02.378
>> [LAUGH]
>> If we make a mistake, and

118
00:06:02.378 --> 00:06:04.413
we don't handle evidence the right way.

119
00:06:04.413 --> 00:06:08.535
Then the problem becomes, that evidence
may be of limited to no value.

120
00:06:08.535 --> 00:06:10.983
And we may perfectly, with the evidence,

121
00:06:10.983 --> 00:06:14.390
be able to prove beyond a doubt

122
00:06:14.390 --> 00:06:17.770
She came over here, grabbed it when

123
00:06:17.770 --> 00:06:19.580
We could see that she did it, right?

124
00:06:19.580 --> 00:06:22.370
But if that isn't dealt with properly,

125
00:06:22.370 --> 00:06:24.220
essentially it's like that
evidence doesn't exist.

126
00:06:24.220 --> 00:06:26.553
Even though we're looking at it,
we know she did it, right?

127
00:06:26.553 --> 00:06:29.289
We can't hold her accountable,
can't say she's guilty,

128
00:06:29.289 --> 00:06:32.600
because the court will never see
that evidence as being legitimate.

129
00:06:32.600 --> 00:06:34.120
>> All right,
Adam you got to tell me here,

130
00:06:34.120 --> 00:06:37.280
what can I do, are there any guidelines or
characteristics that I

00:06:37.280 --> 00:06:41.520
could follow to help prevent that
evidence from being thrown out.

132
00:06:41.520 --> 00:06:42.350
>> Absolutely, so

133
00:06:42.350 --> 00:06:46.159
we talk about the fact that digital
evidence has characteristics, right?

134
00:06:46.159 --> 00:06:50.814
We often talk about them as being things
that have to either be done or attached or

135
00:06:50.814 --> 00:06:53.110
in some way associated with evidence.

136
00:06:53.110 --> 00:06:55.174
We often refer to these as the Bs.

137
00:06:55.174 --> 00:06:56.674
We call them the five Bs, right?

138
00:06:56.674 --> 00:06:58.002
The five Bs of evidence.

139
00:06:58.002 --> 00:07:00.786
So when we talk about
the characteristics of evidence,

140
00:07:00.786 --> 00:07:05.040
we think about the five Bs as in, you
should be this, you should be that, right?

141
00:07:05.040 --> 00:07:07.900
You should be or
the evidence should be admissible.

142
00:07:07.900 --> 00:07:10.027
It should be authentic,
it should be complete.

143
00:07:10.027 --> 00:07:13.312
It should be believable and
it should be reliable.

144
00:07:13.312 --> 00:07:14.520
No particular order, right?

145
00:07:14.520 --> 00:07:16.380
Just generically 5 things, but

146
00:07:16.380 --> 00:07:20.740
we say that the characteristics of
digital evidence for it to be valid.

147
00:07:20.740 --> 00:07:23.179
For it to be adding probative value, for

148
00:07:23.179 --> 00:07:26.637
it to be seen as being legitimate
in the eyes of the court.

149
00:07:26.637 --> 00:07:31.114
Ultimately to be able to be presented
at trial if necessary to further

150
00:07:31.114 --> 00:07:32.280
the discussion.

151
00:07:32.280 --> 00:07:35.648
And create the evidence that may or
may not prove guilt or

152
00:07:35.648 --> 00:07:38.820
innocence before a court, before a jury.

153
00:07:38.820 --> 00:07:43.360
Evidence must stand up to these five
characteristics or prove and show and

154
00:07:43.360 --> 00:07:45.580
have these characteristics
associated with them.

155
00:07:45.580 --> 00:07:49.048
Has to be admissible, authentic,
complete, reliable, and believable.

156
00:07:49.048 --> 00:07:51.906
And you know these are graded scales,
right?

157
00:07:51.906 --> 00:07:55.378
In the sense that what I may think is
believable may not necessarily be what

158
00:07:55.378 --> 00:07:57.340
Cherokee thinks is believable, right?

159
00:07:57.340 --> 00:08:00.955
Our thought process may lead us to

00:23:20.540 --> 00:23:23.570
if they did, what was the impact of that,
right, those kind of things.

497
00:23:23.570 --> 00:23:25.321
>> Adam I have a question
about the individuals.

498
00:23:25.321 --> 00:23:30.456
So I've always kinda wondered this,
looking at selecting your witnesses,

499
00:23:30.456 --> 00:23:34.959
if you decided to use any,
we also wanna keep in mind maybe selecting

500
00:23:34.959 --> 00:23:39.541
the right kind of witnesses too
because like we spoke about earlier,

501
00:23:39.541 --> 00:23:45.174
we don't want to open a vulnerability for
our defense at all in that manner, right?

502
00:23:45.174 --> 00:23:48.915
>> So yeah,
it's a very good point to make.

503
00:23:48.915 --> 00:23:51.850
We don't really select
witnesses per se at this point.

504
00:23:51.850 --> 00:23:53.701
>> That'd be more of the legal counsel-
>> Right, so

505
00:23:53.701 --> 00:23:55.237
let's kind of break it into two parts.

506
00:23:55.237 --> 00:23:57.777
I understand what you're asking,
it's a very good point of clarification.

507
00:23:57.777 --> 00:23:59.607
But let's tell two stories around this.

508
00:23:59.607 --> 00:24:00.743
So can we put the list back up,

509
00:24:00.743 --> 00:24:02.930
because I want to refer to it
as part of what the answer is.

510
00:24:02.930 --> 00:24:06.600
So what's happening here is we're going
through initial incident response, right?

511
00:24:06.600 --> 00:24:10.760
We're showing up, something bad's
happened, they call in the incident

512
00:24:10.760 --> 00:24:14.020
response team and
we're figuring out what's going to happen.

513
00:24:14.020 --> 00:24:16.620
We're the people to put the little
yellow cones down with the numbers and

514
00:24:16.620 --> 00:24:17.910
put the caution tape around and

515
00:24:17.910 --> 00:24:19.280
take the pictures and-
>> We're not there yet.

516
00:24:19.280 --> 00:24:21.380
>> Right, we're that,
that's what we're doing.

517
00:24:21.380 --> 00:24:23.550
So what I'm saying is [CROSSTALK]
>> We're not there for the selection part.

518
00:24:23.550 --> 00:24:27.580
>> Well so what we're doing now is
we're identifying all the things and

519
00:24:27.580 --> 00:24:28.150
the key players.

520
00:24:28.150 --> 00:24:32.380
We are identifying individuals that may
be of interest as the term we would use.

521
00:24:32.380 --> 00:24:34.500
>> Gotcha.
>> They're not witnesses at this point.

522
00:24:34.500 --> 00:24:35.530
In the traditional sense, yes,

523
00:24:35.530 --> 00:24:37.320
they may have witnessed
something that happened there.

524
00:24:37.320 --> 00:24:41.060
Generically called witnesses, but they're
people of interest, meaning people that

525
00:24:41.060 --> 00:24:44.470
have information that we want to
be able to most likely hear from.

526
00:24:44.470 --> 00:24:47.420
Want to have them tell us their story,
want to capture that.

527
00:24:47.420 --> 00:24:51.980
But as an incident responder, we are not
the person who makes the determination

528
00:24:51.980 --> 00:24:54.370
as to who will be a witness
if we go to trial.

529
00:24:54.370 --> 00:24:56.430
>> I see.
>> So ultimately, we tell that story,

530
00:24:56.430 --> 00:24:59.500
we document it,
we may be an expert witness ourselves.

531
00:24:59.500 --> 00:25:01.360
We often are called to testify and

532
00:25:01.360 --> 00:25:04.700
often are called to tell
the story about what we found.

533
00:25:04.700 --> 00:25:07.820
But, the prosecution or the defense,

534
00:25:07.820 --> 00:25:11.000
whoever the lawyers are that
are gonna be involved in one or

535
00:25:11.000 --> 00:25:15.900
both sides of that case, they are gonna
be, through a process known as discovery,

536
00:25:15.900 --> 00:25:19.030
they are going to be given all
the information that the other side has,

537
00:25:19.030 --> 00:25:22.210
has access to and essentially has
built up as part of their case.

538
00:25:22.210 --> 00:25:24.430
That includes things like a witness list,
so you know,

539
00:25:24.430 --> 00:25:26.980
who are the potential people
that the defense wants to call.

540
00:25:26.980 --> 00:25:30.680
The prosecution has the right to see that
list and be able to interview them ahead

541
00:25:30.680 --> 00:25:34.890
of time and understand who they are and
you get their side of the story,

542
00:25:34.890 --> 00:25:37.990
just like the defense has rights to do so
to the prosecution.

543
00:25:37.990 --> 00:25:39.920
>> Right.
>> Very equal in that respect, right.

544
00:25:39.920 --> 00:25:44.970
So those witnesses, people that are going
to have something valuable to offer to

545
00:25:44.970 --> 00:25:48.540
create in the minds of the people that
are gonna hear this case of the judge,

546
00:25:48.540 --> 00:25:51.880
the compelling story that will
hopefully prove their point and

547
00:25:51.880 --> 00:25:54.070
essentially discredit the other side.

548
00:25:54.070 --> 00:25:58.110
Those are decisions made by the opposing
councils, so not made by us.

549
00:25:58.110 --> 00:26:00.720
So, we are in charge of
giving them as complete and

550
00:26:00.720 --> 00:26:03.960
accurate a picture, and
options of what has happened.

551
00:26:03.960 --> 00:26:06.130
But then, in terms of defining that,

552
00:26:06.130 --> 00:26:07.960
that's something that typically
we don't play a part in.

553
00:26:07.960 --> 00:26:09.730
>> Got it.
>> More often than not.

554
00:26:09.730 --> 00:26:11.900
All right, so responses if any,
what did we do?

555
00:26:11.900 --> 00:26:14.910
Did we put anti-malware on the system?

556
00:26:14.910 --> 00:26:15.940
Do we disinfect it?

557
00:26:15.940 --> 00:26:19.300
Do we decide we're gonna shut it down,
take it,

558
00:26:19.300 --> 00:26:21.300
replace the hard drive that went bad?

559
00:26:21.300 --> 00:26:23.490
Just tell the story of what happened,
what did we do?

560
00:26:23.490 --> 00:26:25.850
That's really what response is all about,
right?

561
00:26:25.850 --> 00:26:27.640
So when we're thinking
about the details for

562
00:26:27.640 --> 00:26:30.540
the reported time of
the breach this is that list.

563
00:26:30.540 --> 00:26:33.830
Somebody said to you hey, what are the ten
things you gotta do and you had

564
00:26:33.830 --> 00:26:37.570
to answer a question about it, this is the
stuff you wanna know right here, right?

565
00:26:37.570 --> 00:26:39.790
So make sure you're familiar with this.

566
00:26:39.790 --> 00:26:42.670
I put a note there just since we're here,
we'll just quickly go down the list cuz I

567
00:26:42.670 --> 00:26:45.340
wanna talk about the US
cert categories as well.

568
00:26:45.340 --> 00:26:47.120
I put a note there,
remember the importance of time,

569
00:26:47.120 --> 00:26:49.310
NTP, network time protocol, right?

570
00:26:49.310 --> 00:26:51.040
We've talked in other episodes and

571
00:26:51.040 --> 00:26:55.880
other shows about the fact that NTP
time specification, in terms of knowing

572
00:26:55.880 --> 00:27:00.670
that every machine in an organization is
synced and is running at the same time.

573
00:27:00.670 --> 00:27:05.020
So that logs are time stamped accurately,
access control is accurate,

574
00:27:05.020 --> 00:27:06.240
things of that nature.

575
00:27:06.240 --> 00:27:10.460
You can't under estimate and
over estimate the importance of this.

576
00:27:10.460 --> 00:27:13.500
If you don't have good NTP, good time and

577
00:27:13.500 --> 00:27:18.400
good control of time, you have no basis
to build any kind of incident chain and

578
00:27:18.400 --> 00:27:22.310
any kind of forensic information
that can be seen as being valuable.

579
00:27:22.310 --> 00:27:25.630
Because if we can't validate
that 5:00 AM on this machine,

580
00:27:25.630 --> 00:27:29.640
it's the same as 5:00 AM on every
other machine in this organization,

581
00:27:29.640 --> 00:27:31.540
then time stamps are not accurate.

582
00:27:31.540 --> 00:27:35.020
And whatever happened at 5:00 AM may
actually have happened in a different time

583
00:27:35.020 --> 00:27:36.720
because we have no way of knowing for
sure.

584
00:27:36.720 --> 00:27:40.560
We call this time drift,
where the systems are not synchronized.

585
00:27:40.560 --> 00:27:44.650
And if we have time drift, we have
a fundamental issue with regards to

586
00:27:44.650 --> 00:27:48.350
forensic examination and incident response
cuz we can't authoritatively establish

587
00:27:48.350 --> 00:27:50.070
when something accurately took place.

588
00:27:50.070 --> 00:27:52.660
>> Exactly, if you even think
about the security cameras,

589
00:27:52.660 --> 00:27:55.870
the systems running those machines,
the security cameras.

590
00:27:55.870 --> 00:28:00.220
And if you look at that timeline and
trying to find a good alibi and

591
00:28:00.220 --> 00:28:03.740
things like that that's gonna
punch holes in your defense there.

592
00:28:03.740 --> 00:28:08.200
>> It is, and one of the tell tale signs
or warning signs of hacking that may have

593
00:28:08.200 --> 00:28:11.530
taken place, it's an incident responder
that we look for, is if we know for

594
00:28:11.530 --> 00:28:14.780
a fact we have NTP running and
we find machines that are decoupled,

595
00:28:14.780 --> 00:28:18.570
essentially desynchronized, they're not
running and are not time synced and

596
00:28:18.570 --> 00:28:21.485
there is time drift but
only on certain machines.

597
00:28:21.485 --> 00:28:24.395
That's usually an indicator that
those machines have been the target

598
00:28:24.395 --> 00:28:25.155
of an attack.

599
00:28:25.155 --> 00:28:29.145
They've been desynchronized specifically
to throw off the logging and

600
00:28:29.145 --> 00:28:30.985
the time stamps on the machines, so

601
00:28:30.985 --> 00:28:34.245
we don't have an accurate representation
of when the attack took place.

602
00:28:34.245 --> 00:28:36.900
So this would, in and
of itself, be a warning sign.

603
00:28:36.900 --> 00:28:39.840
When we see, it's not always because
there are legitimate reasons why

604
00:28:39.840 --> 00:28:43.050
certain machines may become unsynchronized
just through the normal course of

605
00:28:43.050 --> 00:28:44.080
operations, right.

606
00:28:44.080 --> 00:28:45.730
Things can happen in other words.

607
00:28:45.730 --> 00:28:50.790
We never wanna assume but we do wanna take
note of and verify interesting facts.

608
00:28:50.790 --> 00:28:54.350
And we would very easily be able to
tell if that decoupling had happened as

609
00:28:54.350 --> 00:28:59.190
a result of just some normal operational
issue, the NTP server stopped working,

610
00:28:59.190 --> 00:29:00.410
we stopped synchronizing.

611
00:29:00.410 --> 00:29:03.220
And we just happen to be at
the beginning of that episode,

612
00:29:03.220 --> 00:29:06.410
unrelated to the incident or
yeah, somebody hacked in and

613
00:29:06.410 --> 00:29:09.040
decoupled those five machines but
everything else was left alone.

614
00:29:09.040 --> 00:29:10.520
So we have to understand that.

615
00:29:10.520 --> 00:29:13.480
One other thing just to talk about
to round us out here, the US CERT.

616
00:29:13.480 --> 00:29:16.270
We've talked about US CERT before,
taking you out to the website,

617
00:29:16.270 --> 00:29:19.840
remember, under Department of
Homeland Security in the United States,

618
00:29:19.840 --> 00:29:22.990
we see a lot of these responder agencies.

619
00:29:22.990 --> 00:29:28.080
So the US CERT is the US federal
government's information or

620
00:29:28.080 --> 00:29:30.420
computer emergency response team.

621
00:29:30.420 --> 00:29:33.680
And so this is the team that gets
the phone call when there's a problem from

622
00:29:33.680 --> 00:29:34.960
a federal agency.

623
00:29:34.960 --> 00:29:36.730
This is the group that
puts out advisory and

624
00:29:36.730 --> 00:29:39.980
update information for
any entity that wants to consume that.

625
00:29:39.980 --> 00:29:42.820
We've been through that and
shown that to you in other episodes.

626
00:29:42.820 --> 00:29:47.210
But they use a categorization ranking,
and you can see CAT 0 through CAT

627
00:29:47.210 --> 00:29:50.610
6 displayed here for
you as to basically what an incident is.

628
00:29:50.610 --> 00:29:53.630
When we talk about categorizing incidents
as one of the things we wanna do and

629
00:29:53.630 --> 00:29:57.260
capture in our reporting, there may
be a standardized methodology and

630
00:29:57.260 --> 00:29:58.690
this is an example of one.

631
00:29:58.690 --> 00:30:02.270
You could see CAT 0, Exercise or
Network Defense Testing.

632
00:30:02.270 --> 00:30:06.500
You'll CAT 3 Malicious Code CAT 6
Investigation, they've laid out

633
00:30:06.500 --> 00:30:11.430
a standardized categorization so that they
can easily attach incidents that occur and

634
00:30:11.430 --> 00:30:15.740
in their reporting here this is a CAT 2
this is a DoS or denial of service attack.

635
00:30:15.740 --> 00:30:19.120
And then they can update and report,
based on that categorization.

636
00:30:19.120 --> 00:30:22.410
So, you wanna have some sort
of categorization built out,

637
00:30:22.410 --> 00:30:24.540
this is a great example of
one that exists out there.

638
00:30:24.540 --> 00:30:28.230
It would be good for you to know this, if
you're planning on taking the ECIH exam.

639
00:30:28.230 --> 00:30:31.060
You may get asked about it
in the relation to US-CERT.

640
00:30:31.060 --> 00:30:34.980
Do other countries have their own version
of this with their own cert teams?

641
00:30:34.980 --> 00:30:38.710
Absolutely, may look identical or
similar to this?

642
00:30:38.710 --> 00:30:42.230
It may, may look slightly different,
it may, hard to say, right?

643
00:30:42.230 --> 00:30:45.810
We didn't put up the 200 that exists
from a survey country in the world,

644
00:30:45.810 --> 00:30:47.650
we just used the random sampling of 1.

645
00:30:47.650 --> 00:30:50.890
But a lot of the standardization
that we see in this industry

646
00:30:50.890 --> 00:30:53.028
will look very similar to this just so
you understand, okay?

647
00:30:53.028 --> 00:30:53.641
>> All right.

648
00:30:53.641 --> 00:30:54.254
>> All right.

649
00:30:54.254 --> 00:30:56.010
>> Well, thanks you Adam so much for

650
00:30:56.010 --> 00:30:59.220
taking the time to explain those ten
areas of interest in addition to

651
00:30:59.220 --> 00:31:03.540
those US CERT categorizations but that
about does it for this particular show.

652
00:31:03.540 --> 00:31:05.710
We're out of time so
I'm gonna go ahead and sign off.

653
00:31:05.710 --> 00:31:08.020
As your show host I'm Cherokee Boose.

654
00:31:08.020 --> 00:31:08.930
>> I'm not Cherokee Boose.

655
00:31:08.930 --> 00:31:11.990
>> [LAUGH] See you next
time here at ITProTV.

656
00:31:11.990 --> 00:31:12.956
>> Take care everybody.

657
00:31:12.956 --> 00:31:18.920
[MUSIC]

658
00:31:18.920 --> 00:31:21.964
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show Adam and Cherokee converse over incident recovery steps such as restoration, system validation, system operations, and system monitoring. Next, they speak on import plans to have in place to prepare an organization for when an incident occurs. Additionally, Adam explains and dissects all that is involved with a Continuity of Operations Plan. Lastly, he offers steps to create a successful Incident Recovery Planning process.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.048
Welcome ITPro.T,v I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.048 --> 00:00:04.487
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.487 --> 00:00:08.330
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.330 --> 00:00:11.945
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.945 --> 00:00:16.834
>> Welcome to your ECIH series,
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:16.834 --> 00:00:20.070
And this episode will be
looking at incident recovery.

7
00:00:20.070 --> 00:00:23.276
And with us today we have Mr. Adam Gordon
in studio to help us cover this topic.

8
00:00:23.276 --> 00:00:25.440
Thank you for joining us today, Adam.

9
00:00:25.440 --> 00:00:27.799
>> Hello everybody, so
hopefully everybody's doing well.

10
00:00:27.799 --> 00:00:31.318
We're gonna talk a bit more or
continue talking I should say,

11
00:00:31.318 --> 00:00:34.095
about incident handling,
incident response,

12
00:00:34.095 --> 00:00:37.363
what it means to be a incident
practitioner of some kind.

13
00:00:37.363 --> 00:00:40.739
When we think about being incident
responder we think about incident

14
00:00:40.739 --> 00:00:43.960
recovery, the idea is that we're
gonna show up on site, right?

15
00:00:43.960 --> 00:00:47.152
We're gonna have some sort of
concern we're gomma address, or

16
00:00:47.152 --> 00:00:49.232
have been asked to come in and to address.

17
00:00:49.232 --> 00:00:52.012
And people look to us to
be that voice of reason,

18
00:00:52.012 --> 00:00:56.532
that stability that they need to have
brought back through a sense of normalcy

19
00:00:56.532 --> 00:01:00.442
returning to what's a probably
very chaotic, very disruptive.

20
00:01:00.442 --> 00:01:01.443
And most likely,

21
00:01:01.443 --> 00:01:05.970
very unusual set of circumstances in
operational environment for them.

22
00:01:05.970 --> 00:01:07.910
And it's important for
us as we start this conversation,

23
00:01:07.910 --> 00:01:11.040
really think about the fact
that if we overreact,

24
00:01:11.040 --> 00:01:16.890
if we get all kinda flustered and crazy,
and we go to pieces so to speak ourselves.

25
00:01:16.890 --> 00:01:21.115
It's gonna be very hard for us not only do
our job, but for us to assure the person

26
00:01:21.115 --> 00:01:25.108
or whoever the entity is that we're
dealing with things are gonna be okay.

27
00:01:25.108 --> 00:01:28.932
A lot of times the most important thing
you need to do with regards to dealing

28
00:01:28.932 --> 00:01:32.452
with an incident is just to assure
the people that are involved that,

29
00:01:32.452 --> 00:01:34.595
whatever's happened, it'll be okay.

30
00:01:34.595 --> 00:01:38.545
You'll figure it out, and that if they
could just relax and help you by not

31
00:01:38.545 --> 00:01:42.384
getting in the way, but simply being
available if you need something.

32
00:01:42.384 --> 00:01:46.335
And in the meantime,
just kinda take a deep breath and relax.

33
00:01:46.335 --> 00:01:49.625
It's gonna make things so much easier for
everybody, for you as the first or

34
00:01:49.625 --> 00:01:52.135
incident responder if you're
there on scene first or

35
00:01:52.135 --> 00:01:53.790
have been called in after the fact.

36
00:01:53.790 --> 00:01:57.220
For the victim or victims,
whoever they may be.

37
00:01:57.220 --> 00:02:01.410
And of course, broadly for the team
at large because more often than not,

38
00:02:01.410 --> 00:02:02.960
you're not the only person responding.

39
00:02:02.960 --> 00:02:05.749
You may be part of a team,
we talked a lot about this methodology,

40
00:02:05.749 --> 00:02:06.779
this thought process.

41
00:02:06.779 --> 00:02:11.429
This mentality of being a member of a cert
or a C-cert and the fact that you may

42
00:02:11.429 --> 00:02:15.700
bring to the table one or
more specialties or areas of knowledge.

43
00:02:15.700 --> 00:02:19.620
And that may be what we call on you for,
and so you may be the database person,

44
00:02:19.620 --> 00:02:21.240
you may be the firewall person.

45
00:02:21.240 --> 00:02:24.430
You may be the person who
understands how to do memory dumps

46
00:02:24.430 --> 00:02:25.590
better than anybody else.

47
00:02:25.590 --> 00:02:30.020
That's your thing, that's your specialty,
that's your superpower, as we say, right?

48
00:02:30.020 --> 00:02:33.789
But whatever that may be,tThat's only one
piece of a broader puzzle with regards to

49
00:02:33.789 --> 00:02:34.328
response.

50
00:02:34.328 --> 00:02:39.130
It's very rare in other words,
that incident response is an army of one.

51
00:02:39.130 --> 00:02:44.120
It's almost without exception gonna be
a group of very talented, dedicated and

52
00:02:44.120 --> 00:02:47.080
very specialized and specially trained

53
00:02:47.080 --> 00:02:52.300
individuals that form a team that may
not always respond to every incident.

54
00:02:52.300 --> 00:02:53.627
If we don't have a database,

55
00:02:53.627 --> 00:02:56.607
in theory if we know ahead of time
there's no databases involved.

56
00:02:56.607 --> 00:03:00.243
We may not need the person that does
databases traditionally as part of that

57
00:03:00.243 --> 00:03:01.290
incident response.

58
00:03:01.290 --> 00:03:04.994
But if they happen to also understand how
to do other things that may be pertinent

59

episodes.description: This show Adam and Cherokee lay down the Law so to speak. They discuss how polices and law impact an organization's infrastructure. Adam provides characteristics of a good security policy in addition to where to find good templates. They also address issues to consider when involving external entities. Adam explains how the fourth Amendment impacts obtaining information through a warrant-less search. Lastly, Adam answers Cherokee's question regarding ones reasonable expectation of privacy.
